this, we propose a dispatch-aware deep neural network (DA-DNN) that accelerates
DC-OTS without relying on pre-solved labels. DA-DNN predicts line states and
passes them through a differentiable DC-OPF layer, using the resulting
generation cost as the loss function so that all physical network constraints
are enforced throughout training and inference. In addition, we adopt a
customized weight-bias initialization that keeps every forward pass feasible
from the first iteration, which allows stable learning on large grids. Once
trained, the proposed DA-DNN produces a provably feasible topology and dispatch
pair in the same time as solving the DCOPF, whereas conventional mixed-integer
solvers become intractable. As a result, the proposed method successfully
captures the economic advantages of OTS while maintaining scalability.

AI.tldr: The paper proposes a dispatch-aware deep neural network (DA-DNN) that accelerates optimal transmission switching (OTS) problems by predicting line states and using a differentiable DC-OPF layer, achieving feasible solutions in the same time as solving DCOPF while maintaining economic advantages.
AI.motivation: Optimal transmission switching (OTS) improves optimal power flow by selectively opening transmission lines, but its mixed-integer formulation creates significant computational complexity that becomes intractable on large grids, especially when using conventional mixed-integer solvers.
AI.method: The authors develop a dispatch-aware deep neural network (DA-DNN) that predicts line states and passes them through a differentiable DC-OPF layer. The method uses generation cost as the loss function to enforce physical network constraints during training and inference, and employs customized weight-bias initialization to maintain feasibility from the first iteration.
AI.result: DA-DNN produces provably feasible topology and dispatch pairs in the same time as solving DCOPF, while conventional mixed-integer solvers become intractable on large grids. The method successfully captures the economic advantages of OTS while maintaining scalability.
AI.conclusion: The proposed DA-DNN method effectively addresses the computational complexity of OTS problems by providing a scalable solution that maintains both feasibility guarantees and economic benefits, making it practical for large-scale power grid optimization.

title: A Comprehensive Evaluation Framework for the Study of the Effects of Facial Filters on Face Recognition Accuracy
summary:
Facial filters are now commonplace for social media users around the world.
Previous work has demonstrated that facial filters can negatively impact
automated face recognition performance. However, these studies focus on small
numbers of hand-picked filters in particular styles. In order to more
effectively incorporate the wide ranges of filters present on various social
media applications, we introduce a framework that allows for larger-scale study
of the impact of facial filters on automated recognition. This framework
includes a controlled dataset of face images, a principled filter selection
process that selects a representative range of filters for experimentation, and
a set of experiments to evaluate the filters' impact on recognition. We
demonstrate our framework with a case study of filters from the American
applications Instagram and Snapchat and the Chinese applications Meitu and Pitu
to uncover cross-cultural differences. Finally, we show how the filtering
effect in a face embedding space can easily be detected and restored to improve
face recognition performance.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces a framework for large-scale evaluation of how facial filters from social media apps affect automated face recognition systems, demonstrating cross-cultural differences and proposing methods to detect and mitigate filtering effects.
AI.motivation: Previous studies on facial filters' impact on face recognition were limited to small numbers of hand-picked filters. There was a need for a comprehensive framework to study the wide range of filters across different social media platforms and understand their effects on automated recognition systems at scale.
AI.method: The authors developed a framework consisting of: (1) a controlled dataset of face images, (2) a principled filter selection process to choose representative filters for experimentation, and (3) systematic experiments to evaluate filters' impact on recognition. They conducted a case study comparing filters from American apps (Instagram, Snapchat) and Chinese apps (Meitu, Pitu).
AI.result: The framework successfully revealed cross-cultural differences in how filters from different applications affect face recognition. The study demonstrated that filtering effects can be detected in face embedding space and that recognition performance varies significantly across different types of filters and cultural contexts.
AI.conclusion: The proposed framework enables large-scale analysis of facial filters' impact on automated face recognition. The filtering effects can be detected and restored in face embedding space to improve recognition performance, providing a practical solution for mitigating filter-induced recognition degradation.

title: Yume: An Interactive World Generation Model
summary:
Yume aims to use images, text, or videos to create an interactive, realistic,
and dynamic world, which allows exploration and control using peripheral
devices or neural signals. In this report, we present a preview version of
\method, which creates a dynamic world from an input image and allows
exploration of the world using keyboard actions. To achieve this high-fidelity
and interactive video world generation, we introduce a well-designed framework,
which consists of four main components, including camera motion quantization,
video generation architecture, advanced sampler, and model acceleration. First,
we quantize camera motions for stable training and user-friendly interaction
using keyboard inputs. Then, we introduce the Masked Video Diffusion
Transformer~(MVDT) with a memory module for infinite video generation in an
autoregressive manner. After that, training-free Anti-Artifact Mechanism (AAM)
and Time Travel Sampling based on Stochastic Differential Equations (TTS-SDE)
are introduced to the sampler for better visual quality and more precise
control. Moreover, we investigate model acceleration by synergistic
optimization of adversarial distillation and caching mechanisms. We use the
high-quality world exploration dataset \sekai to train \method, and it achieves
remarkable results in diverse scenes and applications. All data, codebase, and
model weights are available on https://github.com/stdstu12/YUME. Yume will
update monthly to achieve its original goal. Project page:
https://stdstu12.github.io/YUME-Project/.

AI.tldr: Yume is a system that creates interactive, dynamic virtual worlds from input images, allowing users to explore these worlds through keyboard controls using a novel video generation framework with diffusion transformers.
AI.motivation: To create an interactive, realistic, and dynamic world generation system that allows exploration and control using images, text, or videos as input, enabling users to navigate virtual environments through peripheral devices or neural signals.
AI.method: The framework consists of four main components: (1) camera motion quantization for stable training and keyboard interaction, (2) Masked Video Diffusion Transformer (MVDT) with memory module for infinite autoregressive video generation, (3) training-free Anti-Artifact Mechanism (AAM) and Time Travel Sampling based on Stochastic Differential Equations (TTS-SDE) for improved visual quality and control, and (4) model acceleration through adversarial distillation and caching mechanisms.
AI.result: The system achieves remarkable results in diverse scenes and applications when trained on the high-quality world exploration dataset Sekai, successfully generating interactive video worlds that can be explored using keyboard actions.
AI.conclusion: Yume successfully demonstrates the ability to create interactive, dynamic virtual worlds from input images with high fidelity and user control, with all components (data, code, model weights) made publicly available and planned monthly updates to achieve the original comprehensive goal.

title: OkadaTorch: A Differentiable Programming of Okada Model to Calculate Displacements and Strains from Fault Parameters
summary:
The Okada model is a widely used analytical solution for displacements and
strains caused by a point or rectangular dislocation source in a 3D elastic
half-space. We present OkadaTorch, a PyTorch implementation of the Okada model,
where the entire code is differentiable; gradients with respect to input can be
easily computed using automatic differentiation (AD). Our work consists of two
components: a direct translation of the original Okada model into PyTorch, and
a convenient wrapper interface for efficiently computing gradients and Hessians
with respect to either observation station coordinates or fault parameters.
This differentiable framework is well suited for fault parameter inversion,
including gradient-based optimization, Bayesian inference, and integration with
scientific machine learning (SciML) models. Our code is available here:
https://github.com/msomeya1/OkadaTorch

AI.tldr: OkadaTorch is a PyTorch implementation of the Okada model that enables automatic differentiation for computing gradients and Hessians, making it suitable for fault parameter inversion and scientific machine learning applications.
AI.motivation: The need for a differentiable version of the widely used Okada model to enable gradient-based optimization, Bayesian inference, and integration with scientific machine learning models for fault parameter inversion problems.
AI.method: Direct translation of the original Okada model into PyTorch with automatic differentiation capabilities, plus a wrapper interface for efficiently computing gradients and Hessians with respect to observation station coordinates or fault parameters.
AI.result: A fully differentiable PyTorch implementation of the Okada model that can compute gradients and Hessians automatically, enabling efficient fault parameter inversion workflows.
AI.conclusion: OkadaTorch provides a differentiable framework for the Okada model that facilitates gradient-based optimization, Bayesian inference, and scientific machine learning applications in geophysics and fault parameter estimation.

title: Ultra3D: Efficient and High-Fidelity 3D Generation with Part Attention
summary:
Recent advances in sparse voxel representations have significantly improved
the quality of 3D content generation, enabling high-resolution modeling with
fine-grained geometry. However, existing frameworks suffer from severe
computational inefficiencies due to the quadratic complexity of attention
mechanisms in their two-stage diffusion pipelines. In this work, we propose
Ultra3D, an efficient 3D generation framework that significantly accelerates
sparse voxel modeling without compromising quality. Our method leverages the
compact VecSet representation to efficiently generate a coarse object layout in
the first stage, reducing token count and accelerating voxel coordinate
prediction. To refine per-voxel latent features in the second stage, we
introduce Part Attention, a geometry-aware localized attention mechanism that
restricts attention computation within semantically consistent part regions.
This design preserves structural continuity while avoiding unnecessary global
attention, achieving up to 6.7x speed-up in latent generation. To support this
mechanism, we construct a scalable part annotation pipeline that converts raw
meshes into part-labeled sparse voxels. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
Ultra3D supports high-resolution 3D generation at 1024 resolution and achieves
state-of-the-art performance in both visual fidelity and user preference.

AI.tldr: Ultra3D is an efficient 3D generation framework that accelerates sparse voxel modeling by using VecSet representation for coarse layout generation and Part Attention mechanism for localized refinement, achieving 6.7x speedup while maintaining high-resolution quality at 1024³ resolution.
AI.motivation: Existing sparse voxel 3D generation frameworks suffer from severe computational inefficiencies due to quadratic complexity of attention mechanisms in two-stage diffusion pipelines, limiting their practical application despite enabling high-quality fine-grained geometry modeling.
AI.method: The framework uses a two-stage approach: (1) VecSet representation to efficiently generate coarse object layout with reduced token count for faster voxel coordinate prediction, and (2) Part Attention - a geometry-aware localized attention mechanism that restricts computation within semantically consistent part regions, supported by a scalable part annotation pipeline converting raw meshes to part-labeled sparse voxels.
AI.result: Ultra3D achieves up to 6.7x speed-up in latent generation while supporting high-resolution 3D generation at 1024³ resolution and demonstrates state-of-the-art performance in both visual fidelity and user preference through extensive experiments.
AI.conclusion: Ultra3D successfully addresses computational efficiency bottlenecks in sparse voxel 3D generation by introducing VecSet representation and Part Attention mechanism, enabling practical high-resolution 3D content generation with significant acceleration without quality compromise.

title: HuiduRep: A Robust Self-Supervised Framework for Learning Neural Representations from Extracellular Spikes
summary:
Extracellular recordings are brief voltage fluctuations recorded near
neurons, widely used in neuroscience as the basis for decoding brain activity
at single-neuron resolution. Spike sorting, which assigns each spike to its
source neuron, is a critical step in brain sensing pipelines. However, it
remains challenging under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), electrode drift, and
cross-session variability. In this paper, we propose HuiduRep, a robust
self-supervised representation learning framework that extracts discriminative
and generalizable features from extracellular spike waveforms. By combining
contrastive learning with a denoising autoencoder, HuiduRep learns latent
representations that are robust to noise and drift. Built on HuiduRep, we
develop a spike sorting pipeline that clusters spike representations without
supervision. Experiments on hybrid and real-world datasets demonstrate that
HuiduRep achieves strong robustness and the pipeline matches or outperforms
state-of-the-art tools such as KiloSort4 and MountainSort5. These findings
demonstrate the potential of self-supervised spike representation learning as a
foundational tool for robust and generalizable processing of extracellular
recordings.

AI.tldr: HuiduRep is a self-supervised representation learning framework that improves spike sorting in extracellular neural recordings by combining contrastive learning with denoising autoencoders to create robust features that handle noise, drift, and cross-session variability better than existing methods.
AI.motivation: Spike sorting, which assigns neural spikes to their source neurons, remains challenging under low signal-to-noise ratio, electrode drift, and cross-session variability. Current methods struggle with these conditions, limiting the reliability of single-neuron resolution brain activity decoding in neuroscience applications.
AI.method: The authors propose HuiduRep, a self-supervised representation learning framework that combines contrastive learning with a denoising autoencoder. This approach extracts discriminative and generalizable features from extracellular spike waveforms, learning latent representations that are robust to noise and drift. They then build an unsupervised spike sorting pipeline that clusters these spike representations.
AI.result: Experiments on both hybrid and real-world datasets show that HuiduRep achieves strong robustness to challenging conditions. The complete pipeline matches or outperforms state-of-the-art spike sorting tools including KiloSort4 and MountainSort5 in terms of accuracy and reliability.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates that self-supervised spike representation learning can serve as a foundational tool for robust and generalizable processing of extracellular recordings, offering significant improvements over existing spike sorting methods in challenging experimental conditions.

title: Assessing Medical Training Skills via Eye and Head Movements
summary:
We examined eye and head movements to gain insights into skill development in
clinical settings. A total of 24 practitioners participated in simulated baby
delivery training sessions. We calculated key metrics, including pupillary
response rate, fixation duration, or angular velocity. Our findings indicate
that eye and head tracking can effectively differentiate between trained and
untrained practitioners, particularly during labor tasks. For example,
head-related features achieved an F1 score of 0.85 and AUC of 0.86, whereas
pupil-related features achieved F1 score of 0.77 and AUC of 0.85. The results
lay the groundwork for computational models that support implicit skill
assessment and training in clinical settings by using commodity eye-tracking
glasses as a complementary device to more traditional evaluation methods such
as subjective scores.

AI.tldr: This study used eye and head tracking to assess clinical skills during simulated baby delivery training, showing that these measurements can effectively distinguish between trained and untrained practitioners with high accuracy (F1 scores up to 0.85).
AI.motivation: Traditional evaluation methods in clinical training rely heavily on subjective scores, creating a need for objective, computational approaches to assess practitioner skills during medical procedures like baby delivery.
AI.method: The researchers tracked eye and head movements of 24 practitioners during simulated baby delivery training sessions using eye-tracking glasses, measuring key metrics including pupillary response rate, fixation duration, and angular velocity to differentiate skill levels.
AI.result: Head-related features achieved superior performance with F1 score of 0.85 and AUC of 0.86, while pupil-related features achieved F1 score of 0.77 and AUC of 0.85, effectively distinguishing between trained and untrained practitioners during labor tasks.
AI.conclusion: Eye and head tracking using commodity eye-tracking glasses can serve as an effective complementary tool to traditional subjective evaluation methods, providing objective computational models for implicit skill assessment and training support in clinical settings.

title: A tissue and cell-level annotated H&E and PD-L1 histopathology image dataset in non-small cell lung cancer
comment:
Our dataset is available at 'https://zenodo.org/records/15674785' and
  our code is available at
  'https://github.com/DIAGNijmegen/ignite-data-toolkit'
summary:
The tumor immune microenvironment (TIME) in non-small cell lung cancer
(NSCLC) histopathology contains morphological and molecular characteristics
predictive of immunotherapy response. Computational quantification of TIME
characteristics, such as cell detection and tissue segmentation, can support
biomarker development. However, currently available digital pathology datasets
of NSCLC for the development of cell detection or tissue segmentation
algorithms are limited in scope, lack annotations of clinically prevalent
metastatic sites, and forgo molecular information such as PD-L1
immunohistochemistry (IHC). To fill this gap, we introduce the IGNITE data
toolkit, a multi-stain, multi-centric, and multi-scanner dataset of annotated
NSCLC whole-slide images. We publicly release 887 fully annotated regions of
interest from 155 unique patients across three complementary tasks: (i)
multi-class semantic segmentation of tissue compartments in H&E-stained slides,
with 16 classes spanning primary and metastatic NSCLC, (ii) nuclei detection,
and (iii) PD-L1 positive tumor cell detection in PD-L1 IHC slides. To the best
of our knowledge, this is the first public NSCLC dataset with manual
annotations of H&E in metastatic sites and PD-L1 IHC.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces IGNITE, a comprehensive multi-stain dataset of 887 annotated NSCLC whole-slide images from 155 patients for developing computational pathology algorithms, featuring the first public annotations of metastatic sites and PD-L1 immunohistochemistry.
AI.motivation: Current digital pathology datasets for NSCLC are limited in scope, lack annotations of clinically prevalent metastatic sites, and lack molecular information like PD-L1 immunohistochemistry, which are crucial for developing computational tools to quantify tumor immune microenvironment characteristics that predict immunotherapy response.
AI.method: The researchers created a multi-stain, multi-centric, and multi-scanner dataset called IGNITE with 887 fully annotated regions of interest from 155 unique NSCLC patients, providing annotations for three complementary tasks: multi-class semantic segmentation of tissue compartments in H&E slides (16 classes), nuclei detection, and PD-L1 positive tumor cell detection in PD-L1 IHC slides.
AI.result: The IGNITE dataset provides the first public NSCLC dataset with manual annotations of H&E staining in metastatic sites and PD-L1 immunohistochemistry, enabling comprehensive computational analysis of tumor immune microenvironment characteristics across primary and metastatic NSCLC sites.
AI.conclusion: The IGNITE data toolkit addresses critical gaps in available NSCLC digital pathology datasets by providing comprehensive annotations including metastatic sites and molecular markers, which will support the development of computational biomarkers for immunotherapy response prediction in NSCLC patients.

title: GhostUMAP2: Measuring and Analyzing (r,d)-Stability of UMAP
summary:
Despite the widespread use of Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection
(UMAP), the impact of its stochastic optimization process on the results
remains underexplored. We observed that it often produces unstable results
where the projections of data points are determined mostly by chance rather
than reflecting neighboring structures. To address this limitation, we
introduce (r,d)-stability to UMAP: a framework that analyzes the stochastic
positioning of data points in the projection space. To assess how stochastic
elements, specifically initial projection positions and negative sampling,
impact UMAP results, we introduce "ghosts", or duplicates of data points
representing potential positional variations due to stochasticity. We define a
data point's projection as (r,d)-stable if its ghosts perturbed within a circle
of radius r in the initial projection remain confined within a circle of radius
d for their final positions. To efficiently compute the ghost projections, we
develop an adaptive dropping scheme that reduces a runtime up to 60% compared
to an unoptimized baseline while maintaining approximately 90% of unstable
points. We also present a visualization tool that supports the interactive
exploration of the (r,d)-stability of data points. Finally, we demonstrate the
effectiveness of our framework by examining the stability of projections of
real-world datasets and present usage guidelines for the effective use of our
framework.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces (r,d)-stability framework to analyze and address the instability issues in UMAP's stochastic optimization process, using "ghosts" (duplicated data points) to measure how stochastic elements affect projection stability.
AI.motivation: UMAP's stochastic optimization process produces unstable results where data point projections are determined by chance rather than reflecting true neighboring structures, but this impact remains underexplored in the literature.
AI.method: The authors introduce (r,d)-stability framework that uses "ghosts" (duplicates of data points) to represent potential positional variations due to stochasticity. A data point is (r,d)-stable if ghosts perturbed within radius r in initial projection remain within radius d in final positions. They develop an adaptive dropping scheme for efficient computation and create a visualization tool for interactive exploration.
AI.result: The adaptive dropping scheme reduces runtime by up to 60% compared to unoptimized baseline while maintaining approximately 90% of unstable points. The framework successfully demonstrates effectiveness on real-world datasets and provides practical usage guidelines.
AI.conclusion: The (r,d)-stability framework provides an effective way to analyze and understand UMAP's stochastic behavior, offering both computational efficiency improvements and practical tools for assessing projection stability in real-world applications.

title: Weak Links in LinkedIn: Enhancing Fake Profile Detection in the Age of LLMs
comment:
10 pages, 3 figures, 1 table, accepted for publication at ASONAM
  2025. https://sites.google.com/view/weaklinksinlinkedin/home
summary:
Large Language Models (LLMs) have made it easier to create realistic fake
profiles on platforms like LinkedIn. This poses a significant risk for
text-based fake profile detectors. In this study, we evaluate the robustness of
existing detectors against LLM-generated profiles. While highly effective in
detecting manually created fake profiles (False Accept Rate: 6-7%), the
existing detectors fail to identify GPT-generated profiles (False Accept Rate:
42-52%). We propose GPT-assisted adversarial training as a countermeasure,
restoring the False Accept Rate to between 1-7% without impacting the False
Reject Rates (0.5-2%). Ablation studies revealed that detectors trained on
combined numerical and textual embeddings exhibit the highest robustness,
followed by those using numerical-only embeddings, and lastly those using
textual-only embeddings. Complementary analysis on the ability of prompt-based
GPT-4Turbo and human evaluators affirms the need for robust automated detectors
such as the one proposed in this study.

AI.tldr: This study reveals that existing fake profile detectors fail against LLM-generated profiles (42-52% false accept rate vs 6-7% for manual fakes) and proposes GPT-assisted adversarial training to restore detection effectiveness to 1-7% false accept rate.
AI.motivation: Large Language Models have made it easier to create realistic fake profiles on platforms like LinkedIn, posing significant risks to existing text-based fake profile detection systems that were designed for manually created fake profiles.
AI.method: The researchers evaluated existing detectors against LLM-generated profiles and proposed GPT-assisted adversarial training as a countermeasure. They conducted ablation studies comparing different embedding approaches (combined numerical and textual, numerical-only, and textual-only) and performed complementary analysis using GPT-4Turbo and human evaluators.
AI.result: Existing detectors showed high false accept rates (42-52%) for GPT-generated profiles compared to manually created ones (6-7%). GPT-assisted adversarial training successfully reduced false accept rates to 1-7% while maintaining low false reject rates (0.5-2%). Combined numerical and textual embeddings showed highest robustness, followed by numerical-only, then textual-only embeddings.
AI.conclusion: The study demonstrates that LLM-generated fake profiles pose a serious threat to current detection systems, but GPT-assisted adversarial training can effectively counter this threat. The research affirms the critical need for robust automated detectors capable of handling AI-generated fake profiles.

title: Spintronic Bayesian Hardware Driven by Stochastic Magnetic Domain Wall Dynamics
summary:
As artificial intelligence (AI) advances into diverse applications, ensuring
reliability of AI models is increasingly critical. Conventional neural networks
offer strong predictive capabilities but produce deterministic outputs without
inherent uncertainty estimation, limiting their reliability in safety-critical
domains. Probabilistic neural networks (PNNs), which introduce randomness, have
emerged as a powerful approach for enabling intrinsic uncertainty
quantification. However, traditional CMOS architectures are inherently designed
for deterministic operation and actively suppress intrinsic randomness. This
poses a fundamental challenge for implementing PNNs, as probabilistic
processing introduces significant computational overhead. To address this
challenge, we introduce a Magnetic Probabilistic Computing (MPC) platform-an
energy-efficient, scalable hardware accelerator that leverages intrinsic
magnetic stochasticity for uncertainty-aware computing. This physics-driven
strategy utilizes spintronic systems based on magnetic domain walls (DWs) and
their dynamics to establish a new paradigm of physical probabilistic computing
for AI. The MPC platform integrates three key mechanisms: thermally induced DW
stochasticity, voltage controlled magnetic anisotropy (VCMA), and tunneling
magnetoresistance (TMR), enabling fully electrical and tunable probabilistic
functionality at the device level. As a representative demonstration, we
implement a Bayesian Neural Network (BNN) inference structure and validate its
functionality on CIFAR-10 classification tasks. Compared to standard 28nm CMOS
implementations, our approach achieves a seven orders of magnitude improvement
in the overall figure of merit, with substantial gains in area efficiency,
energy consumption, and speed. These results underscore the MPC platform's
potential to enable reliable and trustworthy physical AI systems.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a Magnetic Probabilistic Computing (MPC) platform that uses intrinsic magnetic stochasticity in spintronic devices to efficiently implement probabilistic neural networks for uncertainty-aware AI, achieving seven orders of magnitude improvement over CMOS implementations.
AI.motivation: Conventional neural networks lack uncertainty estimation capabilities, limiting their reliability in safety-critical applications. While probabilistic neural networks (PNNs) can provide uncertainty quantification, traditional CMOS architectures are designed for deterministic operation and suppress randomness, making PNN implementation computationally expensive and inefficient.
AI.method: The researchers developed a Magnetic Probabilistic Computing platform that leverages intrinsic magnetic stochasticity from spintronic systems based on magnetic domain walls. The platform integrates three key mechanisms: thermally induced domain wall stochasticity, voltage controlled magnetic anisotropy (VCMA), and tunneling magnetoresistance (TMR) to enable fully electrical and tunable probabilistic functionality at the device level.
AI.result: The MPC platform was demonstrated through implementation of a Bayesian Neural Network for CIFAR-10 classification tasks. Compared to standard 28nm CMOS implementations, the approach achieved seven orders of magnitude improvement in overall figure of merit, with substantial gains in area efficiency, energy consumption, and processing speed.
AI.conclusion: The MPC platform demonstrates significant potential for enabling reliable and trustworthy physical AI systems by providing an energy-efficient, scalable hardware solution for uncertainty-aware computing that outperforms traditional CMOS approaches by leveraging physics-driven probabilistic processing.

title: Controllable Video Generation: A Survey
summary:
With the rapid development of AI-generated content (AIGC), video generation
has emerged as one of its most dynamic and impactful subfields. In particular,
the advancement of video generation foundation models has led to growing demand
for controllable video generation methods that can more accurately reflect user
intent. Most existing foundation models are designed for text-to-video
generation, where text prompts alone are often insufficient to express complex,
multi-modal, and fine-grained user requirements. This limitation makes it
challenging for users to generate videos with precise control using current
models. To address this issue, recent research has explored the integration of
additional non-textual conditions, such as camera motion, depth maps, and human
pose, to extend pretrained video generation models and enable more controllable
video synthesis. These approaches aim to enhance the flexibility and practical
applicability of AIGC-driven video generation systems. In this survey, we
provide a systematic review of controllable video generation, covering both
theoretical foundations and recent advances in the field. We begin by
introducing the key concepts and commonly used open-source video generation
models. We then focus on control mechanisms in video diffusion models,
analyzing how different types of conditions can be incorporated into the
denoising process to guide generation. Finally, we categorize existing methods
based on the types of control signals they leverage, including single-condition
generation, multi-condition generation, and universal controllable generation.
For a complete list of the literature on controllable video generation
reviewed, please visit our curated repository at
https://github.com/mayuelala/Awesome-Controllable-Video-Generation.

AI.tldr: This survey systematically reviews controllable video generation methods that extend beyond text-to-video generation by incorporating additional non-textual conditions like camera motion, depth maps, and human pose to enable more precise user control over AI-generated videos.
AI.motivation: Text prompts alone are insufficient to express complex, multi-modal, and fine-grained user requirements for video generation. Current foundation models struggle to provide precise control, making it challenging for users to generate videos that accurately reflect their intent using text-only inputs.
AI.method: The paper provides a systematic survey approach covering: (1) introduction of key concepts and open-source video generation models, (2) analysis of control mechanisms in video diffusion models and how different conditions can be incorporated into the denoising process, and (3) categorization of existing methods based on control signal types including single-condition, multi-condition, and universal controllable generation.
AI.result: The survey presents a comprehensive categorization and analysis of controllable video generation methods, covering both theoretical foundations and recent advances. It systematically organizes existing approaches based on the types of control signals they leverage and provides a curated repository of literature on the topic.
AI.conclusion: The integration of additional non-textual conditions (camera motion, depth maps, human pose) into pretrained video generation models successfully enhances flexibility and practical applicability of AIGC-driven video generation systems, enabling more controllable video synthesis that better reflects user intent.

title: HypoChainer: A Collaborative System Combining LLMs and Knowledge Graphs for Hypothesis-Driven Scientific Discovery
summary:
Modern scientific discovery faces growing challenges in integrating vast and
heterogeneous knowledge critical to breakthroughs in biomedicine and drug
development. Traditional hypothesis-driven research, though effective, is
constrained by human cognitive limits, the complexity of biological systems,
and the high cost of trial-and-error experimentation. Deep learning models,
especially graph neural networks (GNNs), have accelerated prediction
generation, but the sheer volume of outputs makes manual selection for
validation unscalable. Large language models (LLMs) offer promise in filtering
and hypothesis generation, yet suffer from hallucinations and lack grounding in
structured knowledge, limiting their reliability. To address these issues, we
propose HypoChainer, a collaborative visualization framework that integrates
human expertise, LLM-driven reasoning, and knowledge graphs (KGs) to enhance
hypothesis generation and validation. HypoChainer operates in three stages:
First, exploration and contextualization -- experts use retrieval-augmented
LLMs (RAGs) and dimensionality reduction to navigate large-scale GNN
predictions, assisted by interactive explanations. Second, hypothesis chain
formation -- experts iteratively examine KG relationships around predictions
and semantically linked entities, refining hypotheses with LLM and KG
suggestions. Third, validation prioritization -- refined hypotheses are
filtered based on KG-supported evidence to identify high-priority candidates
for experimentation, with visual analytics further strengthening weak links in
reasoning. We demonstrate HypoChainer's effectiveness through case studies in
two domains and expert interviews, highlighting its potential to support
interpretable, scalable, and knowledge-grounded scientific discovery.

AI.tldr: HypoChainer is a collaborative visualization framework that combines human expertise, large language models, and knowledge graphs to enhance scientific hypothesis generation and validation, addressing the limitations of traditional research methods and AI-only approaches in biomedical discovery.
AI.motivation: Traditional hypothesis-driven research is limited by human cognitive constraints, biological system complexity, and high experimental costs. While deep learning models like GNNs accelerate prediction generation, the vast output volume makes manual validation unscalable. LLMs show promise but suffer from hallucinations and lack grounding in structured knowledge, limiting their reliability in scientific discovery.
AI.method: HypoChainer operates through three stages: (1) Exploration and contextualization using retrieval-augmented LLMs and dimensionality reduction to navigate GNN predictions with interactive explanations; (2) Hypothesis chain formation through iterative examination of knowledge graph relationships with LLM and KG suggestions; (3) Validation prioritization by filtering hypotheses based on KG-supported evidence and using visual analytics to strengthen weak reasoning links.
AI.result: The framework's effectiveness was demonstrated through case studies in two domains and expert interviews, showing its capability to support interpretable, scalable, and knowledge-grounded scientific discovery in biomedicine and drug development.
AI.conclusion: HypoChainer successfully integrates human expertise with AI capabilities to overcome the limitations of both traditional research methods and pure AI approaches, providing a practical solution for enhancing scientific hypothesis generation and validation in complex biomedical domains.

title: Reality Proxy: Fluid Interactions with Real-World Objects in MR via Abstract Representations
comment:
16 pages, 9 figures. Accepted for publication in UIST'25 (The 38th
  Annual ACM Symposium on User Interface Software and Technology), Busan,
  Republic of Korea, 28 Sep - 1 Oct 2025
summary:
Interacting with real-world objects in Mixed Reality (MR) often proves
difficult when they are crowded, distant, or partially occluded, hindering
straightforward selection and manipulation. We observe that these difficulties
stem from performing interaction directly on physical objects, where input is
tightly coupled to their physical constraints. Our key insight is to decouple
interaction from these constraints by introducing proxies-abstract
representations of real-world objects. We embody this concept in Reality Proxy,
a system that seamlessly shifts interaction targets from physical objects to
their proxies during selection. Beyond facilitating basic selection, Reality
Proxy uses AI to enrich proxies with semantic attributes and hierarchical
spatial relationships of their corresponding physical objects, enabling novel
and previously cumbersome interactions in MR - such as skimming,
attribute-based filtering, navigating nested groups, and complex multi object
selections - all without requiring new gestures or menu systems. We demonstrate
Reality Proxy's versatility across diverse scenarios, including office
information retrieval, large-scale spatial navigation, and multi-drone control.
An expert evaluation suggests the system's utility and usability, suggesting
that proxy-based abstractions offer a powerful and generalizable interaction
paradigm for future MR systems.

AI.tldr: Reality Proxy is a Mixed Reality system that creates abstract representations (proxies) of real-world objects to overcome interaction difficulties when objects are crowded, distant, or occluded, enabling more sophisticated interactions without new gestures.
AI.motivation: Interacting with real-world objects in Mixed Reality is challenging when objects are crowded, distant, or partially occluded, making selection and manipulation difficult due to tight coupling between input and physical constraints of objects.
AI.method: The system decouples interaction from physical constraints by introducing proxies - abstract representations of real-world objects that users can interact with instead of the physical objects directly. AI is used to enrich proxies with semantic attributes and hierarchical spatial relationships, enabling seamless shifting between physical objects and their proxies during selection.
AI.result: Reality Proxy enables novel MR interactions including skimming, attribute-based filtering, navigating nested groups, and complex multi-object selections without requiring new gestures or menu systems. The system demonstrated versatility across office information retrieval, large-scale spatial navigation, and multi-drone control scenarios.
AI.conclusion: Expert evaluation suggests the system's utility and usability, indicating that proxy-based abstractions offer a powerful and generalizable interaction paradigm for future Mixed Reality systems, successfully addressing fundamental interaction challenges in MR environments.

title: Harmonization in Magnetic Resonance Imaging: A Survey of Acquisition, Image-level, and Feature-level Methods
summary:
Modern medical imaging technologies have greatly advanced neuroscience
research and clinical diagnostics. However, imaging data collected across
different scanners, acquisition protocols, or imaging sites often exhibit
substantial heterogeneity, known as "batch effects" or "site effects". These
non-biological sources of variability can obscure true biological signals,
reduce reproducibility and statistical power, and severely impair the
generalizability of learning-based models across datasets. Image harmonization
aims to eliminate or mitigate such site-related biases while preserving
meaningful biological information, thereby improving data comparability and
consistency. This review provides a comprehensive overview of key concepts,
methodological advances, publicly available datasets, current challenges, and
future directions in the field of medical image harmonization, with a focus on
magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). We systematically cover the full imaging
pipeline, and categorize harmonization approaches into prospective acquisition
and reconstruction strategies, retrospective image-level and feature-level
methods, and traveling-subject-based techniques. Rather than providing an
exhaustive survey, we focus on representative methods, with particular emphasis
on deep learning-based approaches. Finally, we summarize the major challenges
that remain and outline promising avenues for future research.

AI.tldr: This review paper comprehensively examines medical image harmonization techniques, particularly for MRI, focusing on methods to eliminate site-related biases and batch effects that reduce reproducibility and model generalizability across different imaging datasets.
AI.motivation: Medical imaging data collected across different scanners, protocols, or sites exhibit substantial heterogeneity (batch/site effects) that obscure biological signals, reduce reproducibility and statistical power, and impair the generalizability of learning models across datasets. There is a critical need for harmonization methods to improve data comparability and consistency.
AI.method: The paper provides a systematic review categorizing harmonization approaches into: (1) prospective acquisition and reconstruction strategies, (2) retrospective image-level and feature-level methods, and (3) traveling-subject-based techniques. The review covers the full imaging pipeline with particular emphasis on deep learning-based approaches and representative methods rather than exhaustive coverage.
AI.result: The review presents a comprehensive overview of key concepts, methodological advances, publicly available datasets, and current state-of-the-art harmonization techniques in medical imaging, with specific focus on MRI harmonization methods across different categories of approaches.
AI.conclusion: The paper identifies major remaining challenges in medical image harmonization and outlines promising avenues for future research. Image harmonization is essential for eliminating site-related biases while preserving meaningful biological information to improve data comparability, consistency, and model generalizability in medical imaging applications.

title: Prolonging Tool Life: Learning Skillful Use of General-purpose Tools through Lifespan-guided Reinforcement Learning
summary:
In inaccessible environments with uncertain task demands, robots often rely
on general-purpose tools that lack predefined usage strategies. These tools are
not tailored for particular operations, making their longevity highly sensitive
to how they are used. This creates a fundamental challenge: how can a robot
learn a tool-use policy that both completes the task and prolongs the tool's
lifespan? In this work, we address this challenge by introducing a
reinforcement learning (RL) framework that incorporates tool lifespan as a
factor during policy optimization. Our framework leverages Finite Element
Analysis (FEA) and Miner's Rule to estimate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) based
on accumulated stress, and integrates the RUL into the RL reward to guide
policy learning toward lifespan-guided behavior. To handle the fact that RUL
can only be estimated after task execution, we introduce an Adaptive Reward
Normalization (ARN) mechanism that dynamically adjusts reward scaling based on
estimated RULs, ensuring stable learning signals. We validate our method across
simulated and real-world tool use tasks, including Object-Moving and
Door-Opening with multiple general-purpose tools. The learned policies
consistently prolong tool lifespan (up to 8.01x in simulation) and transfer
effectively to real-world settings, demonstrating the practical value of
learning lifespan-guided tool use strategies.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a reinforcement learning framework that teaches robots to use general-purpose tools while considering tool lifespan, incorporating stress-based Remaining Useful Life (RUL) estimation into the reward function and achieving up to 8.01x improvement in tool longevity.
AI.motivation: In inaccessible environments, robots must use general-purpose tools without predefined usage strategies, creating a challenge where tool longevity is highly sensitive to usage patterns. The key problem is learning policies that both complete tasks effectively and prolong tool lifespan.
AI.method: The authors develop an RL framework that integrates tool lifespan considerations into policy optimization by: (1) using Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and Miner's Rule to estimate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) based on accumulated stress, (2) incorporating RUL into the RL reward function, and (3) implementing an Adaptive Reward Normalization (ARN) mechanism to handle the fact that RUL can only be estimated post-execution.
AI.result: The method was validated on simulated and real-world tasks including Object-Moving and Door-Opening with multiple general-purpose tools. Results show consistent tool lifespan prolongation (up to 8.01x improvement in simulation) and effective transfer to real-world settings.
AI.conclusion: The proposed lifespan-guided RL framework successfully enables robots to learn tool-use policies that balance task completion with tool preservation, demonstrating practical value for robotic applications in challenging environments where tool replacement is difficult or impossible.

title: Understanding Prompt Programming Tasks and Questions
summary:
Prompting foundation models (FMs) like large language models (LLMs) have
enabled new AI-powered software features (e.g., text summarization) that
previously were only possible by fine-tuning FMs. Now, developers are embedding
prompts in software, known as prompt programs. The process of prompt
programming requires the developer to make many changes to their prompt. Yet,
the questions developers ask to update their prompt is unknown, despite the
answers to these questions affecting how developers plan their changes. With
the growing number of research and commercial prompt programming tools, it is
unclear whether prompt programmers' needs are being adequately addressed. We
address these challenges by developing a taxonomy of 25 tasks prompt
programmers do and 51 questions they ask, measuring the importance of each task
and question. We interview 16 prompt programmers, observe 8 developers make
prompt changes, and survey 50 developers. We then compare the taxonomy with 48
research and commercial tools. We find that prompt programming is not
well-supported: all tasks are done manually, and 16 of the 51 questions --
including a majority of the most important ones -- remain unanswered. Based on
this, we outline important opportunities for prompt programming tools.

AI.tldr: This paper studies prompt programming practices by developing a taxonomy of 25 tasks and 51 questions that prompt programmers face, finding that current tools inadequately support these needs with most important questions remaining unanswered.
AI.motivation: With the rise of foundation models and prompt-based programming, developers are embedding prompts in software applications. However, it's unclear what specific tasks and questions prompt programmers encounter during development, and whether existing research and commercial tools adequately address their needs.
AI.method: The researchers conducted interviews with 16 prompt programmers, observed 8 developers making prompt changes, and surveyed 50 developers to develop a comprehensive taxonomy. They then compared this taxonomy against 48 existing research and commercial prompt programming tools to assess support gaps.
AI.result: The study identified 25 distinct tasks and 51 questions that prompt programmers deal with. Analysis revealed that all tasks are performed manually, and 16 out of 51 questions (including the majority of the most important ones) remain unanswered by current tools, indicating poor support for prompt programming workflows.
AI.conclusion: Prompt programming is currently not well-supported by existing tools, with significant gaps in addressing developers' most critical needs. The research outlines important opportunities for developing better prompt programming tools that can automate tasks and answer the key questions identified in their taxonomy.

title: Data Virtualization for Machine Learning
summary:
Nowadays, machine learning (ML) teams have multiple concurrent ML workflows
for different applications. Each workflow typically involves many experiments,
iterations, and collaborative activities and commonly takes months and
sometimes years from initial data wrangling to model deployment.
Organizationally, there is a large amount of intermediate data to be stored,
processed, and maintained. \emph{Data virtualization} becomes a critical
technology in an infrastructure to serve ML workflows. In this paper, we
present the design and implementation of a data virtualization service,
focusing on its service architecture and service operations. The infrastructure
currently supports six ML applications, each with more than one ML workflow.
The data virtualization service allows the number of applications and workflows
to grow in the coming years.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a data virtualization service designed to support multiple concurrent ML workflows across different applications, addressing the challenge of managing large amounts of intermediate data in ML pipelines that span months to years.
AI.motivation: ML teams face challenges managing multiple concurrent workflows across different applications, where each workflow involves extensive experiments, iterations, and collaborative activities spanning months to years. The large volume of intermediate data generated requires efficient storage, processing, and maintenance solutions, making data virtualization a critical infrastructure technology.
AI.method: The authors design and implement a data virtualization service with focus on service architecture and service operations. The service is built to handle multiple ML applications and workflows simultaneously, providing a scalable infrastructure solution.
AI.result: The implemented data virtualization service currently supports six ML applications, each containing multiple ML workflows. The infrastructure demonstrates scalability and capability to accommodate growing numbers of applications and workflows.
AI.conclusion: Data virtualization proves to be an effective solution for managing complex ML infrastructure needs. The service successfully supports multiple concurrent ML workflows and provides a foundation for future growth in applications and workflows within ML organizations.

title: VLA-Touch: Enhancing Vision-Language-Action Models with Dual-Level Tactile Feedback
summary:
Tactile feedback is generally recognized to be crucial for effective
interaction with the physical world. However, state-of-the-art
Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models lack the ability to interpret and use
tactile signals, limiting their effectiveness in contact-rich tasks.
Incorporating tactile feedback into these systems is challenging due to the
absence of large multi-modal datasets. We present VLA-Touch, an approach that
enhances generalist robot policies with tactile sensing \emph{without
fine-tuning} the base VLA. Our method introduces two key innovations: (1) a
pipeline that leverages a pretrained tactile-language model that provides
semantic tactile feedback for high-level task planning, and (2) a
diffusion-based controller that refines VLA-generated actions with tactile
signals for contact-rich manipulation. Through real-world experiments, we
demonstrate that our dual-level integration of tactile feedback improves task
planning efficiency while enhancing execution precision. Code is open-sourced
at \href{https://github.com/jxbi1010/VLA-Touch}{this URL}.

AI.tldr: VLA-Touch enhances robot policies with tactile sensing without fine-tuning the base Vision-Language-Action model, using a tactile-language model for semantic feedback and a diffusion controller for action refinement in contact-rich tasks.
AI.motivation: State-of-the-art Vision-Language-Action models lack tactile interpretation capabilities, limiting their effectiveness in contact-rich manipulation tasks. The challenge stems from the absence of large multi-modal datasets that include tactile information.
AI.method: The approach introduces two key innovations: (1) a pipeline using a pretrained tactile-language model that provides semantic tactile feedback for high-level task planning, and (2) a diffusion-based controller that refines VLA-generated actions using tactile signals for precise contact-rich manipulation.
AI.result: Real-world experiments demonstrate that the dual-level integration of tactile feedback improves both task planning efficiency and execution precision in contact-rich manipulation tasks.
AI.conclusion: VLA-Touch successfully integrates tactile sensing into generalist robot policies without requiring fine-tuning of the base VLA model, providing an effective solution for enhancing robot performance in tactile-dependent tasks through semantic feedback and action refinement.

title: Integrating Belief Domains into Probabilistic Logic Programs
comment:
Under consideration in Theory and Practice of Logic Programming
  (TPLP)
summary:
Probabilistic Logic Programming (PLP) under the Distribution Semantics is a
leading approach to practical reasoning under uncertainty. An advantage of the
Distribution Semantics is its suitability for implementation as a Prolog or
Python library, available through two well-maintained implementations, namely
ProbLog and cplint/PITA. However, current formulations of the Distribution
Semantics use point-probabilities, making it difficult to express epistemic
uncertainty, such as arises from, for example, hierarchical classifications
from computer vision models. Belief functions generalize probability measures
as non-additive capacities, and address epistemic uncertainty via interval
probabilities. This paper introduces interval-based Capacity Logic Programs
based on an extension of the Distribution Semantics to include belief
functions, and describes properties of the new framework that make it amenable
to practical applications.

AI.tldr: This paper extends Probabilistic Logic Programming (PLP) with belief functions to handle epistemic uncertainty through interval probabilities, introducing Capacity Logic Programs that generalize the Distribution Semantics beyond point-probabilities.
AI.motivation: Current PLP formulations using the Distribution Semantics rely on point-probabilities, which makes it difficult to express epistemic uncertainty that arises in practical applications like hierarchical classifications from computer vision models. There's a need to handle uncertainty more comprehensively in logic programming frameworks.
AI.method: The paper introduces interval-based Capacity Logic Programs by extending the Distribution Semantics to include belief functions. Belief functions are used as non-additive capacities that generalize probability measures and can represent epistemic uncertainty through interval probabilities rather than point probabilities.
AI.result: The paper develops a new framework called Capacity Logic Programs that can handle epistemic uncertainty through interval probabilities. The framework maintains properties that make it suitable for practical applications while extending beyond the limitations of point-probability approaches.
AI.conclusion: The extended framework successfully addresses the limitation of current PLP implementations by incorporating belief functions and interval probabilities, providing a more comprehensive approach to reasoning under uncertainty that can better handle epistemic uncertainty in practical applications.

title: On Temporal Guidance and Iterative Refinement in Audio Source Separation
summary:
Spatial semantic segmentation of sound scenes (S5) involves the accurate
identification of active sound classes and the precise separation of their
sources from complex acoustic mixtures. Conventional systems rely on a
two-stage pipeline - audio tagging followed by label-conditioned source
separation - but are often constrained by the absence of fine-grained temporal
information critical for effective separation. In this work, we address this
limitation by introducing a novel approach for S5 that enhances the synergy
between the event detection and source separation stages. Our key contributions
are threefold. First, we fine-tune a pre-trained Transformer to detect active
sound classes. Second, we utilize a separate instance of this fine-tuned
Transformer to perform sound event detection (SED), providing the separation
module with detailed, time-varying guidance. Third, we implement an iterative
refinement mechanism that progressively enhances separation quality by
recursively reusing the separator's output from previous iterations. These
advancements lead to significant improvements in both audio tagging and source
separation performance, as demonstrated by our system's second-place finish in
Task 4 of the DCASE Challenge 2025. Our implementation and model checkpoints
are available in our GitHub repository: https://github.com/theMoro/dcase25task4 .

AI.tldr: This paper presents a novel approach for spatial semantic segmentation of sound scenes (S5) that improves upon conventional two-stage pipelines by integrating sound event detection with source separation through fine-tuned Transformers and iterative refinement, achieving second place in DCASE Challenge 2025 Task 4.
AI.motivation: Conventional S5 systems using two-stage pipelines (audio tagging followed by label-conditioned source separation) are limited by the absence of fine-grained temporal information, which is critical for effective sound source separation from complex acoustic mixtures.
AI.method: The approach uses three key components: (1) fine-tuning a pre-trained Transformer for active sound class detection, (2) utilizing a separate instance of the fine-tuned Transformer for sound event detection (SED) to provide detailed time-varying guidance to the separation module, and (3) implementing an iterative refinement mechanism that progressively enhances separation quality by recursively reusing the separator's output from previous iterations.
AI.result: The system achieved significant improvements in both audio tagging and source separation performance, demonstrated by securing second place in Task 4 of the DCASE Challenge 2025. The enhanced synergy between event detection and source separation stages led to better overall S5 performance.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method successfully addresses the limitations of conventional S5 systems by incorporating fine-grained temporal information through sound event detection and iterative refinement, resulting in substantial performance improvements in spatial semantic segmentation of sound scenes.

title: Nearly Minimax Discrete Distribution Estimation in Kullback-Leibler Divergence with High Probability
summary:
We consider the problem of estimating a discrete distribution $p$ with
support of size $K$ and provide both upper and lower bounds with high
probability in KL divergence. We prove that in the worst case, for any
estimator $\widehat{p}$, with probability at least $\delta$, $\text{KL}(p \|
\widehat{p}) \geq C\max\{K,\ln(K)\ln(1/\delta) \}/n $, where $n$ is the sample
size and $C > 0$ is a constant. We introduce a computationally efficient
estimator $p^{\text{OTB}}$, based on Online to Batch conversion and suffix
averaging, and show that with probability at least $1 - \delta$ $\text{KL}(p \|
\widehat{p}) \leq C(K\log(\log(K)) + \ln(K)\ln(1/\delta)) /n$.
  Furthermore, we also show that with sufficiently many observations relative
to $\log(1/\delta)$, the maximum likelihood estimator $\bar{p}$ guarantees that
with probability at least $1-\delta$ $$
  1/6 \chi^2(\bar{p}\|p) \leq 1/4 \chi^2(p\|\bar{p}) \leq \text{KL}(p|\bar{p})
\leq C(K + \log(1/\delta))/n\,, $$ where $\chi^2$ denotes the
$\chi^2$-divergence.

AI.tldr: This paper studies the problem of estimating discrete distributions with finite support, providing both upper and lower bounds for KL divergence with high probability, and introduces an efficient estimator that nearly matches the lower bounds.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to understand the fundamental limits of discrete distribution estimation in terms of KL divergence and to develop computationally efficient estimators that achieve near-optimal performance with high probability guarantees.
AI.method: The authors prove lower bounds using information-theoretic techniques and introduce a computationally efficient estimator called p^OTB based on Online to Batch conversion and suffix averaging. They also analyze the maximum likelihood estimator's performance using chi-squared divergence bounds.
AI.result: They establish a lower bound showing any estimator has KL divergence at least C·max{K, ln(K)ln(1/δ)}/n with probability δ. Their p^OTB estimator achieves KL divergence at most C(K·log(log(K)) + ln(K)ln(1/δ))/n with probability 1-δ, nearly matching the lower bound. For MLE, they provide chi-squared to KL divergence relationships.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides nearly tight characterization of discrete distribution estimation in KL divergence, with the proposed p^OTB estimator being computationally efficient and achieving near-optimal performance that almost matches the fundamental lower bounds.

title: A Versatile Pathology Co-pilot via Reasoning Enhanced Multimodal Large Language Model
summary:
Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have emerged as powerful tools for
computational pathology, offering unprecedented opportunities to integrate
pathological images with language context for comprehensive diagnostic
analysis. These models hold particular promise for automating complex tasks
that traditionally require expert interpretation of pathologists. However,
current MLLM approaches in pathology demonstrate significantly constrained
reasoning capabilities, primarily due to their reliance on expensive
chain-of-thought annotations. Additionally, existing methods remain limited to
simplex application of visual question answering (VQA) at region-of-interest
(ROI) level, failing to address the full spectrum of diagnostic needs such as
ROI classification, detection, segmentation, whole-slide-image (WSI)
classification and VQA in clinical practice. In this study, we present
SmartPath-R1, a versatile MLLM capable of simultaneously addressing both
ROI-level and WSI-level tasks while demonstrating robust pathological reasoning
capability. Our framework combines scale-dependent supervised fine-tuning and
task-aware reinforcement fine-tuning, which circumvents the requirement for
chain-of-thought supervision by leveraging the intrinsic knowledge within MLLM.
Furthermore, SmartPath-R1 integrates multiscale and multitask analysis through
a mixture-of-experts mechanism, enabling dynamic processing for diverse tasks.
We curate a large-scale dataset comprising 2.3M ROI samples and 188K WSI
samples for training and evaluation. Extensive experiments across 72 tasks
validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed approach. This work
represents a significant step toward developing versatile, reasoning-enhanced
AI systems for precision pathology.

AI.tldr: SmartPath-R1 is a versatile multimodal large language model for computational pathology that combines scale-dependent supervised fine-tuning and task-aware reinforcement fine-tuning to perform both ROI-level and WSI-level tasks with enhanced reasoning capabilities, trained on 2.3M ROI and 188K WSI samples.
AI.motivation: Current MLLMs in pathology have constrained reasoning capabilities due to reliance on expensive chain-of-thought annotations and are limited to simple visual question answering at ROI level, failing to address the full spectrum of diagnostic needs including classification, detection, segmentation, and WSI analysis required in clinical practice.
AI.method: The approach combines scale-dependent supervised fine-tuning and task-aware reinforcement fine-tuning to circumvent chain-of-thought supervision requirements by leveraging intrinsic MLLM knowledge. It integrates multiscale and multitask analysis through a mixture-of-experts mechanism for dynamic processing across diverse pathology tasks.
AI.result: SmartPath-R1 demonstrates robust pathological reasoning capability and can simultaneously address both ROI-level and WSI-level tasks. Extensive experiments across 72 tasks validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed approach using a curated dataset of 2.3M ROI samples and 188K WSI samples.
AI.conclusion: This work represents a significant step toward developing versatile, reasoning-enhanced AI systems for precision pathology that can handle the full spectrum of diagnostic tasks required in clinical practice without expensive chain-of-thought annotations.

title: MyGO: Make your Goals Obvious, Avoiding Semantic Confusion in Prostate Cancer Lesion Region Segmentation
summary:
Early diagnosis and accurate identification of lesion location and
progression in prostate cancer (PCa) are critical for assisting clinicians in
formulating effective treatment strategies. However, due to the high semantic
homogeneity between lesion and non-lesion areas, existing medical image
segmentation methods often struggle to accurately comprehend lesion semantics,
resulting in the problem of semantic confusion. To address this challenge, we
propose a novel Pixel Anchor Module, which guides the model to discover a
sparse set of feature anchors that serve to capture and interpret global
contextual information. This mechanism enhances the model's nonlinear
representation capacity and improves segmentation accuracy within lesion
regions. Moreover, we design a self-attention-based Top_k selection strategy to
further refine the identification of these feature anchors, and incorporate a
focal loss function to mitigate class imbalance, thereby facilitating more
precise semantic interpretation across diverse regions. Our method achieves
state-of-the-art performance on the PI-CAI dataset, demonstrating 69.73% IoU
and 74.32% Dice scores, and significantly improving prostate cancer lesion
detection.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a Pixel Anchor Module with self-attention-based Top_k selection strategy to improve prostate cancer lesion segmentation by addressing semantic confusion between lesion and non-lesion areas, achieving state-of-the-art performance on the PI-CAI dataset.
AI.motivation: Early diagnosis and accurate identification of lesion location and progression in prostate cancer are critical for treatment planning. However, existing medical image segmentation methods struggle with semantic confusion due to high semantic homogeneity between lesion and non-lesion areas in prostate cancer images.
AI.method: The authors propose a novel Pixel Anchor Module that guides the model to discover sparse feature anchors for capturing global contextual information. They incorporate a self-attention-based Top_k selection strategy to refine feature anchor identification and use focal loss function to address class imbalance issues.
AI.result: The method achieves state-of-the-art performance on the PI-CAI dataset with 69.73% IoU and 74.32% Dice scores, significantly improving prostate cancer lesion detection compared to existing approaches.
AI.conclusion: The proposed Pixel Anchor Module with self-attention mechanism effectively addresses semantic confusion in prostate cancer lesion segmentation by enhancing nonlinear representation capacity and improving segmentation accuracy, demonstrating superior performance for clinical applications.

title: Confidence Calibration in Vision-Language-Action Models
summary:
Trustworthy robot behavior requires not only high levels of task success but
also that the robot can reliably quantify how likely it is to succeed. To this
end, we present the first systematic study of confidence calibration in
vision-language-action (VLA) foundation models, which map visual observations
and natural-language instructions to low-level robot motor commands. We begin
with extensive benchmarking to understand the critical relationship between
task success and calibration error across multiple datasets and VLA variants,
finding that task performance and calibration are not in tension. Next, we
introduce prompt ensembles for VLAs, a lightweight, Bayesian-inspired algorithm
that averages confidence across paraphrased instructions and consistently
improves calibration. We further analyze calibration over the task time
horizon, showing that confidence is often most reliable after making some
progress, suggesting natural points for risk-aware intervention. Finally, we
reveal differential miscalibration across action dimensions and propose
action-wise Platt scaling, a method to recalibrate each action dimension
independently to produce better confidence estimates. Our aim in this study is
to begin to develop the tools and conceptual understanding necessary to render
VLAs both highly performant and highly trustworthy via reliable uncertainty
quantification.

AI.tldr: This paper presents the first systematic study of confidence calibration in vision-language-action (VLA) foundation models for robotics, introducing methods like prompt ensembles and action-wise Platt scaling to improve uncertainty quantification and make robots more trustworthy.
AI.motivation: Trustworthy robot behavior requires not only high task success rates but also reliable confidence estimation of success likelihood. Current VLA models lack systematic study of confidence calibration, which is crucial for safe and reliable robotic deployment.
AI.method: The paper introduces two main methods: (1) Prompt ensembles - a Bayesian-inspired algorithm that averages confidence across paraphrased instructions, and (2) Action-wise Platt scaling - a calibration method that recalibrates each action dimension independently to improve confidence estimates.
AI.result: Extensive benchmarking shows that task performance and calibration are not in tension. Prompt ensembles consistently improve calibration across datasets and VLA variants. The study reveals that confidence is most reliable after making some progress in tasks, and there's differential miscalibration across action dimensions.
AI.conclusion: The study establishes foundational tools and understanding for developing VLA models that are both highly performant and trustworthy through reliable uncertainty quantification, paving the way for safer robotic systems that can better assess their own capabilities.

title: Learning from Scratch: Structurally-masked Transformer for Next Generation Lib-free Simulation
summary:
This paper proposes a neural framework for power and timing prediction of
multi-stage data path, distinguishing itself from traditional lib-based
analytical methods dependent on driver characterization and load
simplifications. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first
language-based, netlist-aware neural network designed explicitly for standard
cells. Our approach employs two pre-trained neural models of waveform
prediction and delay estimation that directly infer transient waveforms and
propagation delays from SPICE netlists, conditioned on critical physical
parameters such as load capacitance, input slew, and gate size. This method
accurately captures both intrinsic and coupling-induced delay effects without
requiring simplification or interpolation. For multi-stage timing prediction,
we implement a recursive propagation strategy where predicted waveforms from
each stage feed into subsequent stages, cumulatively capturing delays across
the logic chain. This approach ensures precise timing alignment and complete
waveform visibility throughout complex signal pathways. The waveform prediction
utilizes a hybrid CNN-Transformer architecture with netlist-aware node-level
encoding, addressing traditional Transformers' fixed input dimensionality
constraints. Additionally, specialized subnetworks separately handle primary
delay estimation and crosstalk correction. Experimental results demonstrate
SPICE-level accuracy, consistently achieving RMSE below 0.0098 across diverse
industrial circuits. The proposed framework provides a scalable, structurally
adaptable neural alternative to conventional power and timing engines,
demonstrating high fidelity to physical circuit behaviors.

AI.tldr: A neural framework for power and timing prediction in multi-stage data paths that uses pre-trained models to directly infer waveforms and delays from SPICE netlists, achieving SPICE-level accuracy with RMSE below 0.0098 across industrial circuits.
AI.motivation: Traditional library-based analytical methods for power and timing prediction rely on driver characterization and load simplifications, which may not accurately capture complex circuit behaviors. There is a need for a more accurate, scalable approach that can handle intrinsic and coupling-induced delay effects without requiring simplifications or interpolations.
AI.method: The approach uses two pre-trained neural models: one for waveform prediction and one for delay estimation that directly process SPICE netlists. It employs a hybrid CNN-Transformer architecture with netlist-aware node-level encoding to handle variable input dimensions. A recursive propagation strategy feeds predicted waveforms from each stage into subsequent stages. Specialized subnetworks handle primary delay estimation and crosstalk correction separately.
AI.result: The framework achieves SPICE-level accuracy with consistently low RMSE below 0.0098 across diverse industrial circuits. It successfully captures both intrinsic and coupling-induced delay effects while providing precise timing alignment and complete waveform visibility throughout complex signal pathways.
AI.conclusion: The proposed neural framework provides a scalable and structurally adaptable alternative to conventional power and timing engines, demonstrating high fidelity to physical circuit behaviors. This represents the first language-based, netlist-aware neural network designed explicitly for standard cells, offering superior accuracy compared to traditional analytical methods.

title: InstructVLA: Vision-Language-Action Instruction Tuning from Understanding to Manipulation
summary:
To operate effectively in the real world, robots must integrate multimodal
reasoning with precise action generation. However, existing
vision-language-action (VLA) models often sacrifice one for the other, narrow
their abilities to task-specific manipulation data, and suffer catastrophic
forgetting of pre-trained vision-language capabilities. To bridge this gap, we
introduce InstructVLA, an end-to-end VLA model that preserves the flexible
reasoning of large vision-language models (VLMs) while delivering leading
manipulation performance. InstructVLA introduces a novel training paradigm,
Vision-Language-Action Instruction Tuning (VLA-IT), which employs multimodal
training with mixture-of-experts adaptation to jointly optimize textual
reasoning and action generation on both standard VLM corpora and a curated
650K-sample VLA-IT dataset. On in-domain SimplerEnv tasks, InstructVLA achieves
30.5% improvement over SpatialVLA. To evaluate generalization, we introduce
SimplerEnv-Instruct, an 80-task benchmark requiring closed-loop control and
high-level instruction understanding, where it outperforms a fine-tuned OpenVLA
by 92% and an action expert aided by GPT-4o by 29%. Additionally, InstructVLA
surpasses baseline VLMs on multimodal tasks and exhibits inference-time scaling
by leveraging textual reasoning to boost manipulation performance in both
simulated and real-world settings. These results demonstrate InstructVLA's
potential for bridging intuitive and steerable human-robot interaction with
efficient policy learning.

AI.tldr: InstructVLA is an end-to-end vision-language-action model that preserves flexible reasoning capabilities while achieving superior manipulation performance through a novel training paradigm called VLA-IT, demonstrating significant improvements over existing models on both in-domain tasks and generalization benchmarks.
AI.motivation: Existing vision-language-action models often sacrifice multimodal reasoning for action generation or vice versa, are limited to task-specific data, and suffer from catastrophic forgetting of pre-trained vision-language capabilities.
