There's a need for a model that can integrate multimodal reasoning with precise action generation while maintaining the flexible reasoning abilities of large vision-language models.
AI.method: The paper introduces Vision-Language-Action Instruction Tuning (VLA-IT), a novel training paradigm that uses multimodal training with mixture-of-experts adaptation to jointly optimize textual reasoning and action generation. The training combines standard VLM corpora with a curated 650K-sample VLA-IT dataset to preserve reasoning capabilities while learning manipulation skills.
AI.result: InstructVLA achieves 30.5% improvement over SpatialVLA on in-domain SimplerEnv tasks. On the new SimplerEnv-Instruct benchmark (80 tasks requiring closed-loop control and high-level instruction understanding), it outperforms fine-tuned OpenVLA by 92% and GPT-4o-aided action expert by 29%. The model also surpasses baseline VLMs on multimodal tasks and demonstrates inference-time scaling capabilities in both simulated and real-world settings.
AI.conclusion: InstructVLA successfully bridges the gap between intuitive human-robot interaction and efficient policy learning by maintaining flexible reasoning while delivering superior manipulation performance. The results demonstrate the model's potential for enabling more natural and steerable human-robot interactions without compromising on task execution capabilities.

title: Doubly robust outlier resistant inference on causal treatment effect
summary:
Outliers can severely distort causal effect estimation in observational
studies, yet this issue has received limited attention in the literature. Their
influence is especially pronounced in small sample sizes, where detecting and
removing outliers becomes increasingly difficult. Therefore, it is essential to
estimate treatment effects robustly without excluding these influential data
points. To address this, we propose a doubly robust point estimator for the
average treatment effect under a contaminated model that includes outliers.
Robustness in outcome regression is achieved through a robust estimating
equation, while covariate balancing propensity scores (CBPS) ensure resilience
in propensity score modeling.
  To prevent model overfitting due to the inclusion of numerous parameters, we
incorporate variable selection. All these components are unified under a
penalized empirical likelihood framework. For confidence interval estimation,
most existing approaches rely on asymptotic properties, which may be unreliable
in finite samples. We derive an optimal finite-sample confidence interval for
the average treatment effect using our proposed estimating equation, ensuring
that the interval bounds remain unaffected by outliers. Through simulations and
a real-world application involving hypertension data with outliers, we
demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms existing approaches in
both accuracy and robustness.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a doubly robust estimator for average treatment effects that handles outliers without removing them, using robust outcome regression and covariate balancing propensity scores within a penalized empirical likelihood framework, along with finite-sample confidence intervals.
AI.motivation: Outliers severely distort causal effect estimation in observational studies, especially in small samples where detecting and removing outliers is difficult. Existing methods either exclude outliers or rely on asymptotic properties for confidence intervals, which may be unreliable in finite samples.
AI.method: The authors develop a doubly robust point estimator using: (1) robust estimating equations for outcome regression, (2) covariate balancing propensity scores (CBPS) for propensity score modeling, (3) variable selection to prevent overfitting, all unified under a penalized empirical likelihood framework. They also derive optimal finite-sample confidence intervals.
AI.result: Simulations and real-world application on hypertension data demonstrate that the proposed method consistently outperforms existing approaches in both accuracy and robustness when outliers are present.
AI.conclusion: The proposed doubly robust estimator effectively handles outliers in causal inference without exclusion, providing more reliable treatment effect estimates and confidence intervals in finite samples compared to existing methods.

title: Explainable AI for Collaborative Assessment of 2D/3D Registration Quality
summary:
As surgery embraces digital transformation--integrating sophisticated
imaging, advanced algorithms, and robotics to support and automate complex
sub-tasks--human judgment of system correctness remains a vital safeguard for
patient safety. This shift introduces new "operator-type" roles tasked with
verifying complex algorithmic outputs, particularly at critical junctures of
the procedure, such as the intermediary check before drilling or implant
placement. A prime example is 2D/3D registration, a key enabler of image-based
surgical navigation that aligns intraoperative 2D images with preoperative 3D
data. Although registration algorithms have advanced significantly, they
occasionally yield inaccurate results. Because even small misalignments can
lead to revision surgery or irreversible surgical errors, there is a critical
need for robust quality assurance. Current visualization-based strategies alone
have been found insufficient to enable humans to reliably detect 2D/3D
registration misalignments. In response, we propose the first artificial
intelligence (AI) framework trained specifically for 2D/3D registration quality
verification, augmented by explainability features that clarify the model's
decision-making. Our explainable AI (XAI) approach aims to enhance informed
decision-making for human operators by providing a second opinion together with
a rationale behind it. Through algorithm-centric and human-centered
evaluations, we systematically compare four conditions: AI-only, human-only,
human-AI, and human-XAI. Our findings reveal that while explainability features
modestly improve user trust and willingness to override AI errors, they do not
exceed the standalone AI in aggregate performance. Nevertheless, future work
extending both the algorithmic design and the human-XAI collaboration elements
holds promise for more robust quality assurance of 2D/3D registration.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes an explainable AI framework to help human operators verify the quality of 2D/3D registration in surgical navigation systems, addressing the critical need for reliable quality assurance when current visualization methods are insufficient for detecting registration errors.
AI.motivation: Surgery is undergoing digital transformation with advanced imaging and robotics, creating new operator roles that must verify complex algorithmic outputs at critical procedure points. Current visualization-based methods are insufficient for humans to reliably detect 2D/3D registration misalignments, which can lead to revision surgery or irreversible errors, necessitating robust quality assurance solutions.
AI.method: The researchers developed the first AI framework specifically trained for 2D/3D registration quality verification, enhanced with explainability features to clarify the model's decision-making process. They conducted systematic evaluations comparing four conditions: AI-only, human-only, human-AI, and human-XAI through both algorithm-centric and human-centered assessments.
AI.result: The explainability features modestly improved user trust and willingness to override AI errors, but did not exceed the performance of standalone AI in aggregate performance metrics. The study provided insights into how explainable AI affects human-AI collaboration in surgical quality assurance tasks.
AI.conclusion: While the current explainable AI approach shows promise for enhancing human decision-making in surgical registration verification, it does not significantly outperform standalone AI. Future work should focus on extending both algorithmic design and human-XAI collaboration elements to achieve more robust quality assurance for 2D/3D registration in surgical applications.

title: Demonstration of Efficient Predictive Surrogates for Large-scale Quantum Processors
summary:
The ongoing development of quantum processors is driving breakthroughs in
scientific discovery. Despite this progress, the formidable cost of fabricating
large-scale quantum processors means they will remain rare for the foreseeable
future, limiting their widespread application. To address this bottleneck, we
introduce the concept of predictive surrogates, which are classical learning
models designed to emulate the mean-value behavior of a given quantum processor
with provably computational efficiency. In particular, we propose two
predictive surrogates that can substantially reduce the need for quantum
processor access in diverse practical scenarios. To demonstrate their potential
in advancing digital quantum simulation, we use these surrogates to emulate a
quantum processor with up to 20 programmable superconducting qubits, enabling
efficient pre-training of variational quantum eigensolvers for families of
transverse-field Ising models and identification of non-equilibrium Floquet
symmetry-protected topological phases. Experimental results reveal that the
predictive surrogates not only reduce measurement overhead by orders of
magnitude, but can also surpass the performance of conventional,
quantum-resource-intensive approaches. Collectively, these findings establish
predictive surrogates as a practical pathway to broadening the impact of
advanced quantum processors.

AI.tldr: This paper introduces predictive surrogates - classical learning models that can efficiently emulate quantum processors' behavior, reducing the need for expensive quantum hardware access while maintaining computational advantages for quantum simulation tasks.
AI.motivation: The high cost and limited availability of large-scale quantum processors creates a bottleneck that restricts their widespread application in scientific discovery, necessitating alternative approaches to leverage quantum computational advantages more efficiently.
AI.method: The authors propose two predictive surrogates - classical learning models designed to emulate the mean-value behavior of quantum processors with provable computational efficiency. These surrogates are trained to mimic quantum processor outputs without requiring direct quantum hardware access.
AI.result: The predictive surrogates successfully emulated a quantum processor with up to 20 programmable superconducting qubits, enabled efficient pre-training of variational quantum eigensolvers for transverse-field Ising models, identified non-equilibrium Floquet symmetry-protected topological phases, and reduced measurement overhead by orders of magnitude while sometimes outperforming conventional quantum-resource-intensive approaches.
AI.conclusion: Predictive surrogates establish a practical pathway to broaden the impact of advanced quantum processors by significantly reducing quantum hardware requirements while maintaining or exceeding performance, making quantum computational advantages more accessible for diverse applications.

title: Mammo-Mamba: A Hybrid State-Space and Transformer Architecture with Sequential Mixture of Experts for Multi-View Mammography
summary:
Breast cancer (BC) remains one of the leading causes of cancer-related
mortality among women, despite recent advances in Computer-Aided Diagnosis
(CAD) systems. Accurate and efficient interpretation of multi-view mammograms
is essential for early detection, driving a surge of interest in Artificial
Intelligence (AI)-powered CAD models. While state-of-the-art multi-view
mammogram classification models are largely based on Transformer architectures,
their computational complexity scales quadratically with the number of image
patches, highlighting the need for more efficient alternatives. To address this
challenge, we propose Mammo-Mamba, a novel framework that integrates Selective
State-Space Models (SSMs), transformer-based attention, and expert-driven
feature refinement into a unified architecture. Mammo-Mamba extends the
MambaVision backbone by introducing the Sequential Mixture of Experts (SeqMoE)
mechanism through its customized SecMamba block. The SecMamba is a modified
MambaVision block that enhances representation learning in high-resolution
mammographic images by enabling content-adaptive feature refinement. These
blocks are integrated into the deeper stages of MambaVision, allowing the model
to progressively adjust feature emphasis through dynamic expert gating,
effectively mitigating the limitations of traditional Transformer models.
Evaluated on the CBIS-DDSM benchmark dataset, Mammo-Mamba achieves superior
classification performance across all key metrics while maintaining
computational efficiency.

AI.tldr: Mammo-Mamba is a novel AI framework for breast cancer detection in mammograms that combines Selective State-Space Models with transformer attention and expert-driven feature refinement, achieving superior performance while being more computationally efficient than traditional Transformer-based models.
AI.motivation: Breast cancer remains a leading cause of cancer-related mortality among women. While current state-of-the-art multi-view mammogram classification models use Transformer architectures, their computational complexity scales quadratically with image patches, creating a need for more efficient alternatives for accurate and efficient mammogram interpretation in early detection.
AI.method: The paper proposes Mammo-Mamba, which integrates Selective State-Space Models (SSMs), transformer-based attention, and expert-driven feature refinement. It extends the MambaVision backbone by introducing Sequential Mixture of Experts (SeqMoE) mechanism through customized SecMamba blocks that enable content-adaptive feature refinement in high-resolution mammographic images with dynamic expert gating.
AI.result: Mammo-Mamba achieves superior classification performance across all key metrics on the CBIS-DDSM benchmark dataset while maintaining computational efficiency compared to traditional Transformer models.
AI.conclusion: The proposed Mammo-Mamba framework successfully addresses the computational limitations of Transformer-based models while achieving better performance in breast cancer detection from mammograms, demonstrating the effectiveness of combining SSMs with expert-driven feature refinement for medical image analysis.

title: Investigating Training Data Detection in AI Coders
summary:
Recent advances in code large language models (CodeLLMs) have made them
indispensable tools in modern software engineering. However, these models
occasionally produce outputs that contain proprietary or sensitive code
snippets, raising concerns about potential non-compliant use of training data,
and posing risks to privacy and intellectual property. To ensure responsible
and compliant deployment of CodeLLMs, training data detection (TDD) has become
a critical task. While recent TDD methods have shown promise in natural
language settings, their effectiveness on code data remains largely
underexplored. This gap is particularly important given code's structured
syntax and distinct similarity criteria compared to natural language. To
address this, we conduct a comprehensive empirical study of seven
state-of-the-art TDD methods on source code data, evaluating their performance
across eight CodeLLMs. To support this evaluation, we introduce CodeSnitch, a
function-level benchmark dataset comprising 9,000 code samples in three
programming languages, each explicitly labeled as either included or excluded
from CodeLLM training. Beyond evaluation on the original CodeSnitch, we design
targeted mutation strategies to test the robustness of TDD methods under three
distinct settings. These mutation strategies are grounded in the
well-established Type-1 to Type-4 code clone detection taxonomy. Our study
provides a systematic assessment of current TDD techniques for code and offers
insights to guide the development of more effective and robust detection
methods in the future.

AI.tldr: This paper conducts a comprehensive evaluation of training data detection (TDD) methods for code large language models, introducing CodeSnitch benchmark and testing robustness across different code mutation strategies to assess privacy and intellectual property protection.
AI.motivation: CodeLLMs occasionally produce outputs containing proprietary or sensitive code snippets, raising concerns about non-compliant use of training data and risks to privacy and intellectual property. While TDD methods show promise in natural language, their effectiveness on structured code data remains underexplored, creating a critical gap for responsible CodeLLM deployment.
AI.method: The authors conduct an empirical study of seven state-of-the-art TDD methods across eight CodeLLMs using CodeSnitch, a new function-level benchmark dataset with 9,000 code samples in three programming languages. They design targeted mutation strategies based on Type-1 to Type-4 code clone detection taxonomy to test robustness under different settings.
AI.result: The study provides systematic assessment of current TDD techniques for code, evaluating performance across multiple CodeLLMs and testing robustness under various mutation strategies. CodeSnitch serves as a comprehensive benchmark with explicitly labeled training inclusion/exclusion data for reliable evaluation.
AI.conclusion: The research offers the first comprehensive evaluation of TDD methods specifically for code data, revealing gaps in current approaches and providing insights to guide development of more effective and robust detection methods for ensuring responsible CodeLLM deployment in the future.

title: MCM: Mamba-based Cardiac Motion Tracking using Sequential Images in MRI
comment:
Medical Image Computing and Computer-Assisted Intervention (MICCAI),
  Reconstruction and Imaging Motion Estimation Workshop (RIME), 2025
summary:
Myocardial motion tracking is important for assessing cardiac function and
diagnosing cardiovascular diseases, for which cine cardiac magnetic resonance
(CMR) has been established as the gold standard imaging modality. Many existing
methods learn motion from single image pairs consisting of a reference frame
and a randomly selected target frame from the cardiac cycle. However, these
methods overlook the continuous nature of cardiac motion and often yield
inconsistent and non-smooth motion estimations. In this work, we propose a
novel Mamba-based cardiac motion tracking network (MCM) that explicitly
incorporates target image sequence from the cardiac cycle to achieve smooth and
temporally consistent motion tracking. By developing a bi-directional Mamba
block equipped with a bi-directional scanning mechanism, our method facilitates
the estimation of plausible deformation fields. With our proposed motion
decoder that integrates motion information from frames adjacent to the target
frame, our method further enhances temporal coherence. Moreover, by taking
advantage of Mamba's structured state-space formulation, the proposed method
learns the continuous dynamics of the myocardium from sequential images without
increasing computational complexity. We evaluate the proposed method on two
public datasets. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method
quantitatively and qualitatively outperforms both conventional and
state-of-the-art learning-based cardiac motion tracking methods. The code is
available at https://github.com/yjh-0104/MCM.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes MCM, a Mamba-based network for cardiac motion tracking from cine CMR images that uses sequential cardiac cycle information to achieve smoother and more temporally consistent motion estimation compared to existing single image pair methods.
AI.motivation: Existing cardiac motion tracking methods learn from single image pairs (reference + randomly selected target frame), which overlooks the continuous nature of cardiac motion and produces inconsistent, non-smooth motion estimations that don't capture the temporal dynamics of the cardiac cycle.
AI.method: The authors develop a Mamba-based cardiac motion tracking network (MCM) with: (1) bi-directional Mamba blocks with bi-directional scanning mechanism for plausible deformation field estimation, (2) a motion decoder that integrates information from frames adjacent to the target frame for temporal coherence, and (3) leverages Mamba's structured state-space formulation to learn continuous myocardium dynamics from sequential images without increased computational complexity.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation on two public datasets shows the proposed MCM method quantitatively and qualitatively outperforms both conventional and state-of-the-art learning-based cardiac motion tracking methods in terms of motion estimation accuracy and temporal consistency.
AI.conclusion: The proposed Mamba-based approach successfully addresses the limitations of existing cardiac motion tracking methods by incorporating sequential temporal information to achieve smooth, temporally consistent motion tracking while maintaining computational efficiency, demonstrating superior performance for myocardial motion assessment in cine CMR imaging.

title: To Trust or Not to Trust: On Calibration in ML-based Resource Allocation for Wireless Networks
summary:
In next-generation communications and networks, machine learning (ML) models
are expected to deliver not only accurate predictions but also well-calibrated
confidence scores that reflect the true likelihood of correct decisions. This
paper studies the calibration performance of an ML-based outage predictor
within a single-user, multi-resource allocation framework. We first establish
key theoretical properties of this system's outage probability (OP) under
perfect calibration. Importantly, we show that as the number of resources
grows, the OP of a perfectly calibrated predictor approaches the expected
output conditioned on it being below the classification threshold. In contrast,
when only one resource is available, the system's OP equals the model's overall
expected output. We then derive the OP conditions for a perfectly calibrated
predictor. These findings guide the choice of the classification threshold to
achieve a desired OP, helping system designers meet specific reliability
requirements. We also demonstrate that post-processing calibration cannot
improve the system's minimum achievable OP, as it does not introduce new
information about future channel states. Additionally, we show that
well-calibrated models are part of a broader class of predictors that
necessarily improve OP. In particular, we establish a monotonicity condition
that the accuracy-confidence function must satisfy for such improvement to
occur. To demonstrate these theoretical properties, we conduct a rigorous
simulation-based analysis using post-processing calibration techniques: Platt
scaling and isotonic regression. As part of this framework, the predictor is
trained using an outage loss function specifically designed for this system.
Furthermore, this analysis is performed on Rayleigh fading channels with
temporal correlation captured by Clarke's 2D model, which accounts for receiver
mobility.

AI.tldr: This paper analyzes the calibration performance of ML-based outage predictors in multi-resource allocation systems, establishing theoretical properties of outage probability under perfect calibration and demonstrating that well-calibrated models improve system reliability in communication networks.
AI.motivation: Next-generation communication networks require ML models that provide not only accurate predictions but also well-calibrated confidence scores reflecting the true likelihood of correct decisions. Understanding how calibration affects outage probability in multi-resource allocation systems is crucial for meeting specific reliability requirements in communication networks.
AI.method: The authors establish theoretical properties of outage probability under perfect calibration for single-user, multi-resource allocation frameworks. They derive conditions for perfectly calibrated predictors, analyze the relationship between calibration and system performance, and conduct simulation-based analysis using post-processing calibration techniques (Platt scaling and isotonic regression) with outage loss functions on Rayleigh fading channels with temporal correlation.
AI.result: Key findings include: (1) As the number of resources grows, outage probability of perfectly calibrated predictors approaches the expected output conditioned on being below the classification threshold, (2) With one resource, system outage probability equals the model's overall expected output, (3) Post-processing calibration cannot improve minimum achievable outage probability, and (4) Well-calibrated models belong to a class of predictors that necessarily improve outage probability through a monotonicity condition on the accuracy-confidence function.
AI.conclusion: The research provides theoretical guidance for choosing classification thresholds to achieve desired outage probabilities in communication systems. Well-calibrated ML models fundamentally improve system reliability, and the established theoretical framework helps system designers meet specific reliability requirements in next-generation communication networks.

title: Audio-Vision Contrastive Learning for Phonological Class Recognition
summary:
Accurate classification of articulatory-phonological features plays a vital
role in understanding human speech production and developing robust speech
technologies, particularly in clinical contexts where targeted phonemic
analysis and therapy can improve disease diagnosis accuracy and personalized
rehabilitation. In this work, we propose a multimodal deep learning framework
that combines real-time magnetic resonance imaging (rtMRI) and speech signals
to classify three key articulatory dimensions: manner of articulation, place of
articulation, and voicing. We perform classification on 15 phonological classes
derived from the aforementioned articulatory dimensions and evaluate the system
with four audio/vision configurations: unimodal rtMRI, unimodal audio signals,
multimodal middle fusion, and contrastive learning-based audio-vision fusion.
Experimental results on the USC-TIMIT dataset show that our contrastive
learning-based approach achieves state-of-the-art performance, with an average
F1-score of 0.81, representing an absolute increase of 0.23 over the unimodal
baseline. The results confirm the effectiveness of contrastive representation
learning for multimodal articulatory analysis. Our code and processed dataset
will be made publicly available at
https://github.com/DaE-plz/AC_Contrastive_Phonology to support future research.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a multimodal deep learning framework combining real-time MRI and speech signals for classifying articulatory-phonological features, achieving state-of-the-art performance with contrastive learning-based audio-vision fusion (F1-score of 0.81).
AI.motivation: Accurate classification of articulatory-phonological features is crucial for understanding human speech production and developing robust speech technologies, especially in clinical contexts for targeted phonemic analysis, therapy, disease diagnosis, and personalized rehabilitation.
AI.method: The authors develop a multimodal deep learning framework that combines real-time magnetic resonance imaging (rtMRI) and speech signals to classify three articulatory dimensions: manner of articulation, place of articulation, and voicing. They evaluate four configurations: unimodal rtMRI, unimodal audio, multimodal middle fusion, and contrastive learning-based audio-vision fusion.
AI.result: The contrastive learning-based approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on the USC-TIMIT dataset with an average F1-score of 0.81, representing an absolute increase of 0.23 over the unimodal baseline. The system successfully classifies 15 phonological classes derived from the three articulatory dimensions.
AI.conclusion: The results confirm the effectiveness of contrastive representation learning for multimodal articulatory analysis, demonstrating that combining rtMRI and audio signals through contrastive learning significantly improves articulatory-phonological feature classification compared to unimodal approaches.

title: Joint Multi-Target Detection-Tracking in Cognitive Massive MIMO Radar via POMCP
summary:
This correspondence presents a power-aware cognitive radar framework for
joint detection and tracking of multiple targets in a massive multiple-input
multiple-output (MIMO) radar environment. Building on a previous single-target
algorithm based on Partially Observable Monte Carlo Planning (POMCP), we extend
it to the multi-target case by assigning each target an independent POMCP tree,
enabling scalable and efficient planning.
  Departing from uniform power allocation-which is often suboptimal with
varying signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs)-our approach predicts each target's
future angular position and expected received power, based on its estimated
range and radar cross-section (RCS). These predictions guide adaptive waveform
design via a constrained optimization problem that allocates transmit energy to
enhance the detectability of weaker or distant targets, while ensuring
sufficient power for high-SNR targets. The reward function in the underlying
partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) is also modified to
prioritize accurate spatial and power estimation.
  Simulations involving multiple targets with different SNRs confirm the
effectiveness of our method. The proposed framework for the cognitive radar
improves detection probability for low-SNR targets and achieves more accurate
tracking compared to approaches using uniform or orthogonal waveforms. These
results demonstrate the potential of the POMCP-based framework for adaptive,
efficient multi-target radar systems.

AI.tldr: A power-aware cognitive radar framework using Partially Observable Monte Carlo Planning (POMCP) for joint detection and tracking of multiple targets in massive MIMO radar systems, with adaptive waveform design that allocates transmit energy based on predicted target positions and power requirements.
AI.motivation: Traditional uniform power allocation in radar systems is suboptimal when dealing with targets having varying signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). There is a need for adaptive, efficient multi-target radar systems that can intelligently allocate power resources to enhance detection of weaker targets while maintaining performance for high-SNR targets.
AI.method: Extended single-target POMCP algorithm to multi-target case by assigning independent POMCP trees to each target. The approach predicts future angular positions and expected received power based on estimated range and radar cross-section (RCS). Uses constrained optimization for adaptive waveform design and modifies the POMDP reward function to prioritize accurate spatial and power estimation.
AI.result: Simulations with multiple targets at different SNRs showed improved detection probability for low-SNR targets and more accurate tracking performance compared to uniform or orthogonal waveform approaches. The framework demonstrated scalable and efficient planning capabilities for multi-target scenarios.
AI.conclusion: The POMCP-based cognitive radar framework successfully enables adaptive and efficient multi-target radar systems by intelligently allocating transmit energy based on target characteristics, demonstrating significant improvements in detection and tracking performance over conventional approaches.

title: Graph Neural Network Approach to Predicting Magnetization in Quasi-One-Dimensional Ising Systems
summary:
We present a graph-based deep learning framework for predicting the magnetic
properties of quasi-one-dimensional Ising spin systems. The lattice geometry is
encoded as a graph and processed by a graph neural network (GNN) followed by
fully connected layers. The model is trained on Monte Carlo simulation data and
accurately reproduces key features of the magnetization curve, including
plateaus, critical transition points, and the effects of geometric frustration.
It captures both local motifs and global symmetries, demonstrating that GNNs
can infer magnetic behavior directly from structural connectivity. The proposed
approach enables efficient prediction of magnetization without the need for
additional Monte Carlo simulations.

AI.tldr: A graph neural network framework that predicts magnetic properties of quasi-1D Ising spin systems by encoding lattice geometry as graphs, trained on Monte Carlo data to accurately reproduce magnetization curves and critical transitions without requiring additional simulations.
AI.motivation: The need for efficient prediction of magnetic properties in quasi-one-dimensional Ising spin systems without computationally expensive Monte Carlo simulations, while capturing complex phenomena like geometric frustration and critical transitions.
AI.method: A graph-based deep learning framework that encodes lattice geometry as graphs, processes them through graph neural networks (GNNs) followed by fully connected layers, and trains on Monte Carlo simulation data to learn the relationship between structure and magnetic behavior.
AI.result: The model accurately reproduces key magnetization curve features including plateaus, critical transition points, and geometric frustration effects. It successfully captures both local structural motifs and global symmetries, demonstrating GNNs can infer magnetic behavior from structural connectivity alone.
AI.conclusion: Graph neural networks can effectively predict magnetic properties of quasi-1D Ising systems directly from lattice structure, providing an efficient alternative to Monte Carlo simulations while maintaining accuracy in capturing complex magnetic phenomena.

title: Fair Compromises in Participatory Budgeting: a Multi-Agent Deep Reinforcement Learning Approach
summary:
Participatory budgeting is a method of collectively understanding and
addressing spending priorities where citizens vote on how a budget is spent, it
is regularly run to improve the fairness of the distribution of public funds.
Participatory budgeting requires voters to make decisions on projects which can
lead to ``choice overload". A multi-agent reinforcement learning approach to
decision support can make decision making easier for voters by identifying
voting strategies that increase the winning proportion of their vote. This
novel approach can also support policymakers by highlighting aspects of
election design that enable fair compromise on projects. This paper presents a
novel, ethically aligned approach to decision support using multi-agent deep
reinforcement learning modelling. This paper introduces a novel use of a
branching neural network architecture to overcome scalability challenges of
multi-agent reinforcement learning in a decentralized way. Fair compromises are
found through optimising voter actions towards greater representation of voter
preferences in the winning set. Experimental evaluation with real-world
participatory budgeting data reveals a pattern in fair compromise: that it is
achievable through projects with smaller cost.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a multi-agent deep reinforcement learning approach with branching neural networks to support decision-making in participatory budgeting, helping voters develop better voting strategies and policymakers design fairer elections by finding compromises through smaller-cost projects.
AI.motivation: Participatory budgeting suffers from "choice overload" where citizens struggle to make decisions on numerous projects when voting on budget allocation. There's a need for decision support tools that can help voters make better choices while ensuring fair distribution of public funds and enabling policymakers to design more equitable election processes.
AI.method: The paper employs multi-agent deep reinforcement learning with a novel branching neural network architecture to model participatory budgeting scenarios. The approach works in a decentralized manner to overcome scalability challenges and optimizes voter actions to achieve greater representation of voter preferences in winning project sets.
AI.result: Experimental evaluation using real-world participatory budgeting data shows that fair compromises can be achieved, with a notable pattern emerging that fair compromise is attainable through projects with smaller costs. The approach successfully identifies voting strategies that increase the winning proportion of votes.
AI.conclusion: The multi-agent reinforcement learning approach with branching neural networks provides an effective, ethically aligned solution for participatory budgeting decision support. It enables both voters to make better-informed decisions and policymakers to design fairer election processes, with smaller-cost projects being key to achieving fair compromises.

title: CA-Cut: Crop-Aligned Cutout for Data Augmentation to Learn More Robust Under-Canopy Navigation
comment:
Accepted for publication at the 12th European Conference on Mobile
  Robots (ECMR 2025)
summary:
State-of-the-art visual under-canopy navigation methods are designed with
deep learning-based perception models to distinguish traversable space from
crop rows. While these models have demonstrated successful performance, they
require large amounts of training data to ensure reliability in real-world
field deployment. However, data collection is costly, demanding significant
human resources for in-field sampling and annotation. To address this
challenge, various data augmentation techniques are commonly employed during
model training, such as color jittering, Gaussian blur, and horizontal flip, to
diversify training data and enhance model robustness. In this paper, we
hypothesize that utilizing only these augmentation techniques may lead to
suboptimal performance, particularly in complex under-canopy environments with
frequent occlusions, debris, and non-uniform spacing of crops. Instead, we
propose a novel augmentation method, so-called Crop-Aligned Cutout (CA-Cut)
which masks random regions out in input images that are spatially distributed
around crop rows on the sides to encourage trained models to capture high-level
contextual features even when fine-grained information is obstructed. Our
extensive experiments with a public cornfield dataset demonstrate that
masking-based augmentations are effective for simulating occlusions and
significantly improving robustness in semantic keypoint predictions for visual
navigation. In particular, we show that biasing the mask distribution toward
crop rows in CA-Cut is critical for enhancing both prediction accuracy and
generalizability across diverse environments achieving up to a 36.9% reduction
in prediction error. In addition, we conduct ablation studies to determine the
number of masks, the size of each mask, and the spatial distribution of masks
to maximize overall performance.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes Crop-Aligned Cutout (CA-Cut), a novel data augmentation technique for visual under-canopy navigation that strategically masks regions around crop rows to improve model robustness in complex agricultural environments, achieving up to 36.9% reduction in prediction error.
AI.motivation: Existing visual under-canopy navigation models require large amounts of training data for reliable field deployment, but data collection is costly and time-consuming. Traditional augmentation techniques may be insufficient for complex under-canopy environments with frequent occlusions, debris, and non-uniform crop spacing.
AI.method: The authors propose Crop-Aligned Cutout (CA-Cut), a masking-based augmentation technique that randomly masks regions in input images spatially distributed around crop rows. This encourages models to capture high-level contextual features even when fine-grained information is obstructed, simulating real-world occlusions in agricultural environments.
AI.result: Extensive experiments on a public cornfield dataset show that CA-Cut significantly improves robustness in semantic keypoint predictions for visual navigation. The method achieves up to 36.9% reduction in prediction error and enhances both prediction accuracy and generalizability across diverse environments compared to traditional augmentation techniques.
AI.conclusion: Masking-based augmentations are effective for simulating occlusions in under-canopy navigation tasks. Biasing mask distribution toward crop rows is critical for performance improvement. The study includes ablation studies on mask number, size, and spatial distribution to optimize overall performance.

title: Integrating Physics-Based and Data-Driven Approaches for Probabilistic Building Energy Modeling
summary:
Building energy modeling is a key tool for optimizing the performance of
building energy systems. Historically, a wide spectrum of methods has been
explored -- ranging from conventional physics-based models to purely
data-driven techniques. Recently, hybrid approaches that combine the strengths
of both paradigms have gained attention. These include strategies such as
learning surrogates for physics-based models, modeling residuals between
simulated and observed data, fine-tuning surrogates with real-world
measurements, using physics-based outputs as additional inputs for data-driven
models, and integrating the physics-based output into the loss function the
data-driven model. Despite this progress, two significant research gaps remain.
First, most hybrid methods focus on deterministic modeling, often neglecting
the inherent uncertainties caused by factors like weather fluctuations and
occupant behavior. Second, there has been little systematic comparison within a
probabilistic modeling framework. This study addresses these gaps by evaluating
five representative hybrid approaches for probabilistic building energy
modeling, focusing on quantile predictions of building thermodynamics in a
real-world case study. Our results highlight two main findings. First, the
performance of hybrid approaches varies across different building room types,
but residual learning with a Feedforward Neural Network performs best on
average. Notably, the residual approach is the only model that produces
physically intuitive predictions when applied to out-of-distribution test data.
Second, Quantile Conformal Prediction is an effective procedure for calibrating
quantile predictions in case of indoor temperature modeling.

AI.tldr: This study evaluates five hybrid approaches that combine physics-based and data-driven methods for probabilistic building energy modeling, finding that residual learning with feedforward neural networks performs best and produces physically intuitive predictions for out-of-distribution data.
AI.motivation: Two significant research gaps exist in building energy modeling: (1) most hybrid methods focus on deterministic modeling while neglecting inherent uncertainties from weather fluctuations and occupant behavior, and (2) there has been little systematic comparison within a probabilistic modeling framework.
AI.method: The study evaluates five representative hybrid approaches for probabilistic building energy modeling, focusing on quantile predictions of building thermodynamics in a real-world case study. The approaches include learning surrogates for physics-based models, modeling residuals between simulated and observed data, fine-tuning surrogates with real-world measurements, using physics-based outputs as additional inputs, and integrating physics-based output into loss functions.
AI.result: Two main findings emerged: (1) hybrid approach performance varies across different building room types, with residual learning using Feedforward Neural Networks performing best on average and being the only model producing physically intuitive predictions for out-of-distribution test data, and (2) Quantile Conformal Prediction effectively calibrates quantile predictions for indoor temperature modeling.
AI.conclusion: Residual learning with Feedforward Neural Networks is the most effective hybrid approach for probabilistic building energy modeling, particularly for handling out-of-distribution scenarios, and Quantile Conformal Prediction provides effective calibration for uncertainty quantification in indoor temperature predictions.

title: Clustering-based hard negative sampling for supervised contrastive speaker verification
summary:
In speaker verification, contrastive learning is gaining popularity as an
alternative to the traditionally used classification-based approaches.
Contrastive methods can benefit from an effective use of hard negative pairs,
which are different-class samples particularly challenging for a verification
model due to their similarity. In this paper, we propose CHNS - a
clustering-based hard negative sampling method, dedicated for supervised
contrastive speaker representation learning. Our approach clusters embeddings
of similar speakers, and adjusts batch composition to obtain an optimal ratio
of hard and easy negatives during contrastive loss calculation. Experimental
evaluation shows that CHNS outperforms a baseline supervised contrastive
approach with and without loss-based hard negative sampling, as well as a
state-of-the-art classification-based approach to speaker verification by as
much as 18 % relative EER and minDCF on the VoxCeleb dataset using two
lightweight model architectures.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes CHNS, a clustering-based hard negative sampling method for supervised contrastive learning in speaker verification that clusters similar speaker embeddings and optimizes batch composition to improve verification performance by up to 18% relative improvement over existing methods.
AI.motivation: Speaker verification traditionally relies on classification-based approaches, but contrastive learning is emerging as a promising alternative. However, effective use of hard negative pairs (similar-sounding speakers from different classes) remains challenging. Existing methods don't optimally balance hard and easy negatives during training, limiting the potential of contrastive learning for speaker verification.
AI.method: The paper introduces CHNS (Clustering-based Hard Negative Sampling), which clusters embeddings of similar speakers and strategically adjusts batch composition during training. The method calculates an optimal ratio of hard negatives (challenging similar speakers) to easy negatives during contrastive loss computation, ensuring more effective supervised contrastive learning for speaker representation.
AI.result: CHNS achieves up to 18% relative improvement in Equal Error Rate (EER) and minimum Detection Cost Function (minDCF) on the VoxCeleb dataset compared to baseline supervised contrastive approaches and state-of-the-art classification-based methods. The improvements were demonstrated using two lightweight model architectures, showing consistent performance gains.
AI.conclusion: The clustering-based hard negative sampling approach effectively enhances supervised contrastive learning for speaker verification by intelligently managing the difficulty balance in training pairs. CHNS demonstrates superior performance over both traditional classification-based methods and existing contrastive approaches, making it a promising technique for improving speaker verification systems.

title: IndoorBEV: Joint Detection and Footprint Completion of Objects via Mask-based Prediction in Indoor Scenarios for Bird's-Eye View Perception
summary:
Detecting diverse objects within complex indoor 3D point clouds presents
significant challenges for robotic perception, particularly with varied object
shapes, clutter, and the co-existence of static and dynamic elements where
traditional bounding box methods falter. To address these limitations, we
propose IndoorBEV, a novel mask-based Bird's-Eye View (BEV) method for indoor
mobile robots.
  In a BEV method, a 3D scene is projected into a 2D BEV grid which handles
naturally occlusions and provides a consistent top-down view aiding to
distinguish static obstacles from dynamic agents. The obtained 2D BEV results
is directly usable to downstream robotic tasks like navigation, motion
prediction, and planning. Our architecture utilizes an axis compact encoder and
a window-based backbone to extract rich spatial features from this BEV map. A
query-based decoder head then employs learned object queries to concurrently
predict object classes and instance masks in the BEV space. This mask-centric
formulation effectively captures the footprint of both static and dynamic
objects regardless of their shape, offering a robust alternative to bounding
box regression. We demonstrate the effectiveness of IndoorBEV on a custom
indoor dataset featuring diverse object classes including static objects
  and dynamic elements like robots and miscellaneous items, showcasing its
potential for robust indoor scene understanding.

AI.tldr: IndoorBEV is a novel mask-based Bird's-Eye View method that projects 3D indoor point clouds to 2D BEV grids for robust object detection, using query-based decoder to predict object classes and instance masks instead of traditional bounding boxes.
AI.motivation: Traditional bounding box methods struggle with diverse object shapes, clutter, and co-existence of static and dynamic elements in complex indoor 3D point clouds, creating significant challenges for robotic perception systems.
AI.method: The method projects 3D scenes into 2D BEV grids using an axis compact encoder and window-based backbone to extract spatial features, then employs a query-based decoder head with learned object queries to predict object classes and instance masks in BEV space.
AI.result: IndoorBEV effectively captures footprints of both static and dynamic objects regardless of shape, demonstrated on a custom indoor dataset with diverse object classes including static objects, robots, and miscellaneous items.
AI.conclusion: The mask-centric BEV formulation provides a robust alternative to bounding box regression for indoor scene understanding, with results directly usable for downstream robotic tasks like navigation, motion prediction, and planning.

title: Optimal differentially private kernel learning with random projection
summary:
Differential privacy has become a cornerstone in the development of
privacy-preserving learning algorithms. This work addresses optimizing
differentially private kernel learning within the empirical risk minimization
(ERM) framework. We propose a novel differentially private kernel ERM algorithm
based on random projection in the reproducing kernel Hilbert space using
Gaussian processes. Our method achieves minimax-optimal excess risk for both
the squared loss and Lipschitz-smooth convex loss functions under a local
strong convexity condition. We further show that existing approaches based on
alternative dimension reduction techniques, such as random Fourier feature
mappings or $\ell_2$ regularization, yield suboptimal generalization
performance. Our key theoretical contribution also includes the derivation of
dimension-free generalization bounds for objective perturbation-based private
linear ERM -- marking the first such result that does not rely on noisy
gradient-based mechanisms. Additionally, we obtain sharper generalization
bounds for existing differentially private kernel ERM algorithms. Empirical
evaluations support our theoretical claims, demonstrating that random
projection enables statistically efficient and optimally private kernel
learning. These findings provide new insights into the design of differentially
private algorithms and highlight the central role of dimension reduction in
balancing privacy and utility.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a novel differentially private kernel learning algorithm using random projection in reproducing kernel Hilbert spaces that achieves minimax-optimal excess risk while providing dimension-free generalization bounds for private linear ERM.
AI.motivation: The need to optimize differentially private kernel learning within empirical risk minimization framework while balancing privacy protection and learning utility, addressing limitations of existing approaches that yield suboptimal generalization performance.
AI.method: A differentially private kernel ERM algorithm based on random projection in reproducing kernel Hilbert space using Gaussian processes, combined with objective perturbation techniques rather than noisy gradient-based mechanisms.
AI.result: The algorithm achieves minimax-optimal excess risk for squared loss and Lipschitz-smooth convex loss functions under local strong convexity. Derives first dimension-free generalization bounds for objective perturbation-based private linear ERM and obtains sharper bounds for existing differentially private kernel ERM algorithms.
AI.conclusion: Random projection enables statistically efficient and optimally private kernel learning, outperforming alternative dimension reduction techniques like random Fourier features or ℓ2 regularization. The work highlights dimension reduction as central to balancing privacy and utility in differentially private algorithms.

title: Reasoning-Driven Retrosynthesis Prediction with Large Language Models via Reinforcement Learning
summary:
Retrosynthesis planning, essential in organic synthesis and drug discovery,
has greatly benefited from recent AI-driven advancements. Nevertheless,
existing methods frequently face limitations in both applicability and
explainability. Traditional graph-based and sequence-to-sequence models often
lack generalized chemical knowledge, leading to predictions that are neither
consistently accurate nor easily explainable. To address these challenges, we
introduce RetroDFM-R, a reasoning-based large language model (LLM) designed
specifically for chemical retrosynthesis. Leveraging large-scale reinforcement
learning guided by chemically verifiable rewards, RetroDFM-R significantly
enhances prediction accuracy and explainability. Comprehensive evaluations
demonstrate that RetroDFM-R significantly outperforms state-of-the-art methods,
achieving a top-1 accuracy of 65.0% on the USPTO-50K benchmark. Double-blind
human assessments further validate the chemical plausibility and practical
utility of RetroDFM-R's predictions. RetroDFM-R also accurately predicts
multistep retrosynthetic routes reported in the literature for both real-world
drug molecules and perovskite materials. Crucially, the model's explicit
reasoning process provides human-interpretable insights, thereby enhancing
trust and practical value in real-world retrosynthesis applications.

AI.tldr: RetroDFM-R is a reasoning-based large language model for chemical retrosynthesis that uses reinforcement learning with chemically verifiable rewards to achieve 65.0% top-1 accuracy on USPTO-50K benchmark while providing explainable predictions.
AI.motivation: Existing retrosynthesis planning methods (graph-based and sequence-to-sequence models) face limitations in applicability and explainability, often lacking generalized chemical knowledge and producing predictions that are neither consistently accurate nor easily explainable.
AI.method: The paper introduces RetroDFM-R, a reasoning-based large language model specifically designed for chemical retrosynthesis, leveraging large-scale reinforcement learning guided by chemically verifiable rewards to enhance both prediction accuracy and explainability.
AI.result: RetroDFM-R achieves 65.0% top-1 accuracy on the USPTO-50K benchmark, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods. Double-blind human assessments validate the chemical plausibility and practical utility. The model accurately predicts multistep retrosynthetic routes for real-world drug molecules and perovskite materials.
AI.conclusion: RetroDFM-R successfully addresses the limitations of existing retrosynthesis methods by providing both high accuracy and explainability through its explicit reasoning process, offering human-interpretable insights that enhance trust and practical value in real-world retrosynthesis applications.

title: Scalable DC Optimization via Adaptive Frank-Wolfe Algorithms
summary:
We consider the problem of minimizing a difference of (smooth) convex
functions over a compact convex feasible region $P$, i.e., $\min_{x \in P} f(x)
- g(x)$, with smooth $f$ and Lipschitz continuous $g$. This computational study
builds upon and complements the framework of Maskan et al. [2025] by
integrating advanced Frank-Wolfe variants to reduce computational overhead. We
empirically show that constrained DC problems can be efficiently solved using a
combination of the Blended Pairwise Conditional Gradients (BPCG) algorithm
[Tsuji et al., 2022] with warm-starting and the adaptive error bound from
Maskan et al. [2025]. The result is a highly efficient and scalable
projection-free algorithm for constrained DC optimization.

AI.tldr: The paper presents an efficient projection-free algorithm for constrained difference-of-convex (DC) optimization by combining Blended Pairwise Conditional Gradients (BPCG) with warm-starting and adaptive error bounds, building on Maskan et al.'s framework.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to reduce computational overhead in solving constrained DC optimization problems (minimizing f(x) - g(x) over a compact convex region) by developing more efficient algorithms that avoid expensive projection operations.
AI.method: The method integrates advanced Frank-Wolfe variants, specifically the Blended Pairwise Conditional Gradients (BPCG) algorithm with warm-starting techniques and adaptive error bounds from Maskan et al.'s framework to create a projection-free approach.
AI.result: The empirical results demonstrate that constrained DC problems can be efficiently solved using the proposed combination of BPCG with warm-starting and adaptive error bounds, resulting in a highly efficient and scalable algorithm.
AI.conclusion: The study successfully shows that the integration of BPCG with warm-starting and adaptive error bounds creates a highly efficient and scalable projection-free algorithm for constrained DC optimization, effectively reducing computational overhead compared to existing methods.

title: Citation Recommendation using Deep Canonical Correlation Analysis
summary:
Recent advances in citation recommendation have improved accuracy by
leveraging multi-view representation learning to integrate the various
modalities present in scholarly documents. However, effectively combining
multiple data views requires fusion techniques that can capture complementary
information while preserving the unique characteristics of each modality. We
propose a novel citation recommendation algorithm that improves upon linear
Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) methods by applying Deep CCA (DCCA), a
neural network extension capable of capturing complex, non-linear relationships
between distributed textual and graph-based representations of scientific
articles. Experiments on the large-scale DBLP (Digital Bibliography & Library
Project) citation network dataset demonstrate that our approach outperforms
state-of-the-art CCA-based methods, achieving relative improvements of over 11%
in Mean Average Precision@10, 5% in Precision@10, and 7% in Recall@10. These
gains reflect more relevant citation recommendations and enhanced ranking
quality, suggesting that DCCA's non-linear transformations yield more
expressive latent representations than CCA's linear projections.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a Deep CCA-based citation recommendation algorithm that uses neural networks to capture non-linear relationships between textual and graph-based representations of scientific articles, achieving significant improvements over linear CCA methods on the DBLP dataset.
AI.motivation: Existing citation recommendation methods using linear Canonical Correlation Analysis (CCA) have limitations in capturing complex, non-linear relationships between multiple data modalities (textual and graph-based representations) in scholarly documents, which limits their effectiveness in combining complementary information from different views.
AI.method: The authors propose a Deep CCA (DCCA) approach that extends linear CCA with neural networks to learn non-linear transformations and capture complex relationships between distributed textual and graph-based representations of scientific articles for citation recommendation.
AI.result: Experiments on the DBLP citation network dataset show the proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art CCA-based methods with relative improvements of over 11% in Mean Average Precision@10, 5% in Precision@10, and 7% in Recall@10, demonstrating more relevant citation recommendations and enhanced ranking quality.
AI.conclusion: Deep CCA's non-linear transformations yield more expressive latent representations compared to linear CCA projections, leading to improved citation recommendation performance by better capturing complementary information from multiple data modalities while preserving unique characteristics of each modality.

title: Time Deep Gradient Flow Method for pricing American options
summary:
In this research, we explore neural network-based methods for pricing
multidimensional American put options under the BlackScholes and Heston model,
extending up to five dimensions. We focus on two approaches: the Time Deep
Gradient Flow (TDGF) method and the Deep Galerkin Method (DGM). We extend the
TDGF method to handle the free-boundary partial differential equation inherent
in American options. We carefully design the sampling strategy during training
to enhance performance. Both TDGF and DGM achieve high accuracy while
outperforming conventional Monte Carlo methods in terms of computational speed.
In particular, TDGF tends to be faster during training than DGM.

AI.tldr: This paper compares neural network methods (TDGF and DGM) for pricing multidimensional American put options, showing both methods achieve high accuracy and faster computation than Monte Carlo methods, with TDGF being faster in training.
AI.motivation: American options pricing in multiple dimensions is computationally challenging due to the free-boundary problem and curse of dimensionality. Traditional Monte Carlo methods are slow, motivating the need for faster neural network-based approaches that can handle up to five dimensions under different market models.
AI.method: The paper employs two neural network approaches: (1) Time Deep Gradient Flow (TDGF) method extended to handle free-boundary PDEs of American options, and (2) Deep Galerkin Method (DGM). Both methods are implemented with carefully designed sampling strategies during training and tested under BlackScholes and Heston models.
AI.result: Both TDGF and DGM achieve high accuracy in pricing multidimensional American put options while significantly outperforming conventional Monte Carlo methods in computational speed. TDGF demonstrates faster training times compared to DGM, making it particularly efficient for this application.
AI.conclusion: Neural network-based methods, particularly TDGF and DGM, provide effective solutions for pricing multidimensional American options, offering superior computational efficiency over traditional Monte Carlo approaches while maintaining high accuracy across different market models.

title: Enabling Cyber Security Education through Digital Twins and Generative AI
summary:
Digital Twins (DTs) are gaining prominence in cybersecurity for their ability
to replicate complex IT (Information Technology), OT (Operational Technology),
and IoT (Internet of Things) infrastructures, allowing for real time
monitoring, threat analysis, and system simulation. This study investigates how
integrating DTs with penetration testing tools and Large Language Models (LLMs)
can enhance cybersecurity education and operational readiness. By simulating
realistic cyber environments, this approach offers a practical, interactive
framework for exploring vulnerabilities and defensive strategies. At the core
of this research is the Red Team Knife (RTK), a custom penetration testing
toolkit aligned with the Cyber Kill Chain model. RTK is designed to guide
learners through key phases of cyberattacks, including reconnaissance,
exploitation, and response within a DT powered ecosystem. The incorporation of
Large Language Models (LLMs) further enriches the experience by providing
intelligent, real-time feedback, natural language threat explanations, and
adaptive learning support during training exercises. This combined DT LLM
framework is currently being piloted in academic settings to develop hands on
skills in vulnerability assessment, threat detection, and security operations.
Initial findings suggest that the integration significantly improves the
effectiveness and relevance of cybersecurity training, bridging the gap between
theoretical knowledge and real-world application. Ultimately, the research
demonstrates how DTs and LLMs together can transform cybersecurity education to
meet evolving industry demands.

AI.tldr: This paper presents a framework that integrates Digital Twins (DTs) with Large Language Models (LLMs) and penetration testing tools to enhance cybersecurity education, featuring the Red Team Knife (RTK) toolkit that simulates realistic cyber environments for hands-on training.
AI.motivation: Traditional cybersecurity education lacks practical, real-world experience and struggles to bridge the gap between theoretical knowledge and actual application. There's a need for more effective training methods that can simulate complex IT/OT/IoT infrastructures and provide interactive learning environments for cybersecurity professionals.
AI.method: The research develops a combined framework integrating Digital Twins with Large Language Models and penetration testing tools. The core component is the Red Team Knife (RTK), a custom penetration testing toolkit aligned with the Cyber Kill Chain model. LLMs provide real-time feedback, natural language threat explanations, and adaptive learning support during training exercises in DT-powered ecosystems.
AI.result: Initial findings from academic pilot programs show that the DT-LLM integration significantly improves the effectiveness and relevance of cybersecurity training. The framework successfully enables hands-on skills development in vulnerability assessment, threat detection, and security operations while providing realistic cyber environment simulations.
AI.conclusion: The research demonstrates that combining Digital Twins and Large Language Models can transform cybersecurity education by providing practical, interactive frameworks that better prepare learners for real-world cybersecurity challenges and meet evolving industry demands.

title: Debiased maximum-likelihood estimators for hazard ratios under machine-learning adjustment
summary:
Previous studies have shown that hazard ratios between treatment groups
estimated with the Cox model are uninterpretable because the indefinite
baseline hazard of the model fails to identify temporal change in the risk set
composition due to treatment assignment and unobserved factors among multiple,
contradictory scenarios. To alleviate this problem, especially in studies based
on observational data with uncontrolled dynamic treatment and real-time
measurement of many covariates, we propose abandoning the baseline hazard and
using machine learning to explicitly model the change in the risk set with or
without latent variables. For this framework, we clarify the context in which
hazard ratios can be causally interpreted, and then develop a method based on
Neyman orthogonality to compute debiased maximum-likelihood estimators of
hazard ratios. Computing the constructed estimators is more efficient than
computing those based on weighted regression with marginal structural Cox
models. Numerical simulations confirm that the proposed method identifies the
ground truth with minimal bias. These results lay the foundation for developing
a useful, alternative method for causal inference with uncontrolled,
observational data in modern epidemiology.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes a machine learning-based alternative to the Cox model for causal inference in survival analysis, addressing the uninterpretability of hazard ratios by explicitly modeling risk set changes and using debiased maximum-likelihood estimators based on Neyman orthogonality.
AI.motivation: Previous studies showed that hazard ratios from Cox models are uninterpretable because the indefinite baseline hazard fails to identify temporal changes in risk set composition due to treatment assignment and unobserved factors. This problem is particularly severe in observational studies with uncontrolled dynamic treatment and real-time covariate measurement.
AI.method: The authors propose abandoning the baseline hazard and using machine learning to explicitly model changes in the risk set with or without latent variables. They develop a method based on Neyman orthogonality to compute debiased maximum-likelihood estimators of hazard ratios, which is more computationally efficient than weighted regression with marginal structural Cox models.
AI.result: Numerical simulations confirm that the proposed method identifies the ground truth with minimal bias and is computationally more efficient than existing approaches based on marginal structural Cox models.
AI.conclusion: The results establish a foundation for developing an alternative method for causal inference with uncontrolled, observational data in modern epidemiology, providing a more interpretable and efficient approach to survival analysis in complex observational settings.

title: Mindfulness Meditation and Respiration: Accelerometer-Based Respiration Rate and Mindfulness Progress Estimation to Enhance App Engagement and Mindfulness Skills
comment:
Accepted in Proc. ACM Interact. Mob. Wearable Ubiquitous Technology
  (IMWUT)
summary:
Mindfulness training is widely recognized for its benefits in reducing
depression, anxiety, and loneliness. With the rise of smartphone-based
mindfulness apps, digital meditation has become more accessible, but sustaining
long-term user engagement remains a challenge. This paper explores whether
respiration biosignal feedback and mindfulness skill estimation enhance system
usability and skill development. We develop a smartphone's accelerometer-based
respiration tracking algorithm, eliminating the need for additional wearables.
Unlike existing methods, our approach accurately captures slow breathing
patterns typical of mindfulness meditation. Additionally, we introduce the
first quantitative framework to estimate mindfulness skills-concentration,
sensory clarity, and equanimity-based on accelerometer-derived respiration
data. We develop and test our algorithms on 261 mindfulness sessions in both
controlled and real-world settings. A user study comparing an experimental
group receiving biosignal feedback with a control group using a standard app
shows that respiration feedback enhances system usability. Our respiration
tracking model achieves a mean absolute error (MAE) of 1.6 breaths per minute,
closely aligning with ground truth data, while our mindfulness skill estimation
attains F1 scores of 80-84% in tracking skill progression. By integrating
respiration tracking and mindfulness estimation into a commercial app, we
demonstrate the potential of smartphone sensors to enhance digital mindfulness
training.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a smartphone accelerometer-based system that tracks breathing patterns and estimates mindfulness skills (concentration, sensory clarity, equanimity) to enhance digital meditation apps, achieving high accuracy in respiration tracking (1.6 BPM error) and skill estimation (80-84% F1 scores).
AI.motivation: While mindfulness apps are widely accessible, sustaining long-term user engagement remains challenging. The research is motivated by the need to enhance digital mindfulness training through objective feedback mechanisms that can improve system usability and skill development without requiring additional wearable devices.
AI.method: The researchers developed a smartphone accelerometer-based respiration tracking algorithm specifically designed to capture slow breathing patterns typical of mindfulness meditation. They also created the first quantitative framework to estimate three mindfulness skills (concentration, sensory clarity, and equanimity) based on accelerometer-derived respiration data. The system was tested on 261 mindfulness sessions in both controlled and real-world settings.
AI.result: The respiration tracking model achieved a mean absolute error (MAE) of 1.6 breaths per minute compared to ground truth data. The mindfulness skill estimation framework attained F1 scores of 80-84% in tracking skill progression. A user study comparing groups with and without biosignal feedback demonstrated that respiration feedback enhances system usability.
AI.conclusion: The integration of respiration tracking and mindfulness skill estimation into smartphone apps demonstrates the potential of using built-in smartphone sensors to enhance digital mindfulness training. The system successfully provides objective feedback without requiring additional wearables, potentially improving long-term user engagement in mindfulness practices.

title: CASCADE: LLM-Powered JavaScript Deobfuscator at Google
summary:
Software obfuscation, particularly prevalent in JavaScript, hinders code
comprehension and analysis, posing significant challenges to software testing,
static analysis, and malware detection. This paper introduces CASCADE, a novel
hybrid approach that integrates the advanced coding capabilities of Gemini with
the deterministic transformation capabilities of a compiler Intermediate
Representation (IR), specifically JavaScript IR (JSIR). By employing Gemini to
identify critical prelude functions, the foundational components underlying the
most prevalent obfuscation techniques, and leveraging JSIR for subsequent code
transformations, CASCADE effectively recovers semantic elements like original
strings and API names, and reveals original program behaviors. This method
overcomes limitations of existing static and dynamic deobfuscation techniques,
eliminating hundreds to thousands of hardcoded rules while achieving
reliability and flexibility. CASCADE is already deployed in Google's production
environment, demonstrating substantial improvements in JavaScript deobfuscation
efficiency and reducing reverse engineering efforts.

AI.tldr: CASCADE is a hybrid JavaScript deobfuscation approach that combines Gemini's AI capabilities with JavaScript IR transformations to effectively recover obfuscated code semantics, eliminating the need for thousands of hardcoded rules while achieving better reliability and efficiency than existing methods.
AI.motivation: JavaScript obfuscation significantly hinders code comprehension and analysis, creating major challenges for software testing, static analysis, and malware detection. Existing static and dynamic deobfuscation techniques have limitations and require extensive hardcoded rules, making them inflexible and unreliable.
AI.method: CASCADE employs a hybrid approach that integrates Gemini's advanced coding capabilities to identify critical prelude functions (foundational components of obfuscation techniques) with the deterministic transformation capabilities of JavaScript Intermediate Representation (JSIR) for subsequent code transformations.
AI.result: CASCADE effectively recovers semantic elements like original strings and API names, reveals original program behaviors, eliminates hundreds to thousands of hardcoded rules, and demonstrates substantial improvements in JavaScript deobfuscation efficiency. The method is already deployed in Google's production environment.
AI.conclusion: CASCADE successfully overcomes the limitations of existing deobfuscation techniques by combining AI capabilities with compiler IR transformations, achieving superior reliability, flexibility, and efficiency in JavaScript deobfuscation while reducing reverse engineering efforts in real-world production environments.

title: Sequential Bayesian Design for Efficient Surrogate Construction in the Inversion of Darcy Flows
summary:
Inverse problems governed by partial differential equations (PDEs) play a
crucial role in various fields, including computational science, image
processing, and engineering. Particularly, Darcy flow equation is a fundamental
equation in fluid mechanics, which plays a crucial role in understanding fluid
flow through porous media. Bayesian methods provide an effective approach for
solving PDEs inverse problems, while their numerical implementation requires
numerous evaluations of computationally expensive forward solvers. Therefore,
the adoption of surrogate models with lower computational costs is essential.
However, constructing a globally accurate surrogate model for high-dimensional
complex problems demands high model capacity and large amounts of data. To
address this challenge, this study proposes an efficient locally accurate
surrogate that focuses on the high-probability regions of the true likelihood
in inverse problems, with relatively low model complexity and few training data
requirements. Additionally, we introduce a sequential Bayesian design strategy
to acquire the proposed surrogate since the high-probability region of the
likelihood is unknown. The strategy treats the posterior evolution process of
sequential Bayesian design as a Gaussian process, enabling algorithmic
acceleration through one-step ahead prior. The complete algorithmic framework
is referred to as Sequential Bayesian design for locally accurate surrogate
(SBD-LAS). Finally, three experiments based the Darcy flow equation demonstrate
the advantages of the proposed method in terms of both inversion accuracy and
computational speed.

AI.tldr: This paper proposes SBD-LAS, a sequential Bayesian design method that creates locally accurate surrogate models for solving inverse problems in PDEs (particularly Darcy flow equations) by focusing on high-probability likelihood regions, reducing computational costs while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: Bayesian methods for solving PDE inverse problems require numerous evaluations of expensive forward solvers. While surrogate models can reduce computational costs, constructing globally accurate surrogates for high-dimensional complex problems demands high model capacity and large training datasets, which is computationally prohibitive.
AI.method: The paper develops SBD-LAS (Sequential Bayesian design for locally accurate surrogate), which creates locally accurate surrogates focusing on high-probability regions of the true likelihood rather than global accuracy. A sequential Bayesian design strategy is used to identify these high-probability regions, treating the posterior evolution as a Gaussian process and using one-step ahead prior for algorithmic acceleration.
AI.result: Three experiments based on Darcy flow equations demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior performance in both inversion accuracy and computational speed compared to existing approaches, requiring relatively low model complexity and fewer training data.
AI.conclusion: The SBD-LAS framework successfully addresses the computational challenges of Bayesian inverse problems by strategically focusing surrogate model accuracy on the most important regions, providing an efficient solution for PDE inverse problems in fluid mechanics and other applications.

title: Deep Generative Learning of Magnetic Frustration in Artificial Spin Ice from Magnetic Force Microscopy Images
summary:
Increasingly large datasets of microscopic images with atomic resolution
facilitate the development of machine learning methods to identify and analyze
subtle physical phenomena embedded within the images. In this work, microscopic
images of honeycomb lattice spin-ice samples serve as datasets from which we
automate the calculation of net magnetic moments and directional orientations
of spin-ice configurations. In the first stage of our workflow, machine
learning models are trained to accurately predict magnetic moments and
directions within spin-ice structures. Variational Autoencoders (VAEs), an
emergent unsupervised deep learning technique, are employed to generate
high-quality synthetic magnetic force microscopy (MFM) images and extract
latent feature representations, thereby reducing experimental and segmentation
errors. The second stage of proposed methodology enables precise identification
and prediction of frustrated vertices and nanomagnetic segments, effectively
correlating structural and functional aspects of microscopic images. This
facilitates the design of optimized spin-ice configurations with controlled
frustration patterns, enabling potential on-demand synthesis.

AI.tldr: This paper develops a machine learning workflow using Variational Autoencoders to automatically analyze honeycomb lattice spin-ice samples from microscopic images, enabling identification of magnetic moments, frustrated vertices, and nanomagnetic segments for optimized spin-ice design.
AI.motivation: Large datasets of atomic-resolution microscopic images create opportunities for machine learning to identify subtle physical phenomena. The need exists to automate calculation of magnetic moments and orientations in spin-ice configurations, and to correlate structural and functional aspects for optimized design.
AI.method: A two-stage workflow: (1) Train machine learning models to predict magnetic moments and directions in spin-ice structures using Variational Autoencoders (VAEs) to generate synthetic magnetic force microscopy images and extract latent features, reducing experimental errors; (2) Identify and predict frustrated vertices and nanomagnetic segments to correlate structure and function.
AI.result: The methodology successfully enables precise identification and prediction of frustrated vertices and nanomagnetic segments in honeycomb lattice spin-ice samples, effectively correlating structural and functional aspects of microscopic images.
AI.conclusion: The developed machine learning approach facilitates the design of optimized spin-ice configurations with controlled frustration patterns, enabling potential on-demand synthesis of spin-ice materials with desired properties.
